headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Patrick and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the second quarter and fiscal year 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Walters, you may be
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Patrick and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the second quarter and fiscal year 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Walters, you may begin the conference.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and welcome to our second quarter of fiscal 2011 call. Joining me on the call today are President and CEO, Tim Main; and our Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander. This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabi
componenttext:
Thank you and welcome to our second quarter of fiscal 2011 call. Joining me on the call today are President and CEO, Tim Main; and our Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander. This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, www.jabil.com in the Investors section. Our second quarter press release and webcast with slides are also available on our website. In those slides, you will find the financial information we'll cover during this conference call. We ask that you follow our presentation with the slides on the website, beginning with Slide 2 now. Our forward-looking statement. During this conference call, we will be making forward-looking statements, including those regarding the anticipated outlook for our business, our currently expected third quarter of fiscal 2011 net revenue and earnings results, our long-term outlook for our company and improvements in our operational efficiency and financial performance. These statements are based on current expectations, forecasts and assumptions involving risks and uncertainties that could cause actual outcomes and results to differ materially. The extensive list of these risks and uncertainties are identified in our annual report on Form 10-K for this fiscal year ended August 31, 2010, on subsequent reports on the Form 10-Q and Form 8-K and in our other securities filings. Jabil disclaims any obligation or intention to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
Today's call will begin with some comments and highlights from Forbes Alexander on our second fiscal quarter, as well as some forward guidance on our third fiscal quarter of 2011. Tim Main will then follow with some macro and Jabil-specific comments about our performance, our model and our current outlook. We will then open it up to questions from call attendees. I'll now turn the call over to Forbes.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Beth and hello, everyone. I ask you to refer to Slides 3 and 4. Net revenue for the second quarter, $3.9 billion, an increase of 30.8% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $104.6 million. This compares to $61.8 million of GAAP o
componenttext:
Thank you, Beth and hello, everyone. I ask you to refer to Slides 3 and 4. Net revenue for the second quarter, $3.9 billion, an increase of 30.8% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $104.6 million. This compares to $61.8 million of GAAP operating income on revenues of $3 billion for the same period in the prior year. Core operating income, excluding amortization of intangibles, stock-based compensation, charges associated with the acquisition of sites in France and Italy increased 76.2%, $168.4 million. It represents 4.3% of revenue. This compares to $95.6 million or 3.2% for the same period in the prior year. As expected, on a sequential basis, revenue decreased 3.8% in the second quarter while core operating income decreased by 7.4%. Core diluted earnings per share $0.54, an increase of 86.2% over the prior year. 
Please now refer to Slides 5 and 6 for revenue mix and core operating income by each of the segments on our second fiscal quarter. Our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment grew by 0.5% sequentially. On a yearly basis, the segment grew 47%. Revenue was approximately $1.4 billion, representing 35% of total company revenue in the second quarter. Core operating income was 6.1% of revenue. Revenue and core operating income performance were impacted in the quarter as a result of semi-cap equipment revenues below our previous expectations and incremental investments within Specialized Services to support ongoing program wins and ramps in the second half of the fiscal year. The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment increased by 6% sequentially. On a yearly basis, this segment grew by 19%. Revenue was approximately $1.2 billion, representing 32% of total company revenue in the second quarter. Core operating income for the segment was 4.6% of revenue. Our High Velocity segment decreased by 15% sequentially. On a yearly basis, this segment grew by 27%. Revenue was approximately $1.3 billion, representing 33% of total company revenue in the quarter. Core operating income for the segment was 2% of revenue. We are pleased with the progress we are making as we move this segment as part of our operating income range of 2% to 2.5%. 
Now, I ask you to refer to Slides 7, 8 and 9, which accompany my commentary on elements of our second quarter operating and balance sheet performance. Selling, general and administration expenses were $121.5 million and represented 3.1% of revenue. The section development costs, $6.5 million in the quarter, tangible common amortization was $5.7 million. Stock-based compensation was $20.3 million in the quarter. Charges associated with the recently acquired sites in France and Italy was $37.6 million. Our net interest expense for the quarter was $25.9 million. At the current rate, our net core operating income is 16.4%. Our sales cycle in the second quarter decreased by five days in the previous quarter to 11 days. Inventory turns remained consistent at seven. Cash flow from operations was $458.3 million. The core return on invested capital for the quarter was 25.8% and cash and cash equivalents were $902.3 million. 
At the end of the second quarter, there were no outstanding balances on our revolver. Our capital expenditures during the quarter were approximately $106 million as we continue to invest in infrastructure to support our targeted markets and capabilities. $56 million was associated with our Diversified Manufacturing Services group, $13 million in our Enterprise & Infrastructure, $7 million in our high velocity and $30 million in our IT and building infrastructure. Depreciation in the quarter was approximately $71.3 million and core EBITDA was $239.6 million or 6.1% of revenue, consistent with that of our first fiscal quarter. 
In summary, we are extremely pleased with the results of our second quarter. Our goal and plan to fundamentally shift the revenue and income profile of the company to provide overall sustainable operating performance positions to accelerate as we move through the second half of the fiscal year. 
I will now ask you to refer to slides 11 and 12. I'd like to take a few minutes to discuss the recent events in Japan and the recent acquisition of sites in France and Italy. Our heartfelt condolences go out to all those impacted by the recent natural disaster in Japan. Our operations and employees in Tokyo were not directly impacted by the events. We immediately established the supply chain command center and continued to work with customers and suppliers to assess the full scope of any impact to the continuity of supply and assess best strategies to mitigate any such impact. Towards the end of our second fiscal quarter, we acquired operations in France and Italy, with the primary motivation being to sustain customer relationships. We are currently in the process of developing a long-term business plan for these sites. We expect revenues to represent approximately 1.5% of overall quarterly revenue guidance in the third fiscal quarter. The acquisition of these sites is not expected to impact our ability to hit our 2011 and long-term goals. 
I'd now like to provide you with our third quarter fiscal 2011 guidance. The natural disaster in Japan may have an impact on supply components to our global manufacturing operations. However, the extent of this impact is not known at this time. Therefore, the guidance I'm providing excludes the impact of potential supply disruptions on these results. Now, I ask you to refer to Slides 13 and 14. We expect revenue in the third quarter on a year-over-year basis to increase by approximately 21% or 6% sequentially to a range of $4.1 billion to $4.2 billion. The Diversified Manufacturing Services group is expected to increase by 6% sequentially. The Enterprise & Infrastructure group is expected to increase by 8% sequentially, of which approximately half of this growth is associated with the acquisition of operations in France and Italy. The balance reflects new business awards in existing customer, the wireless telecommunications programs, which will ramp over the next two quarters, while our high velocity segment is expected to increase 3% sequentially. 
Core operating income is estimated to be in the range of $175 million to $185 million. Please keep in mind that this includes the range of $5 million to $10 million of operating losses associated with the sites in France and Italy. Core operating margin is expected to be in the range of 4.3% to 4.4%. And as a result, core earnings per share in the range of $0.55 to $0.59 per diluted share. Selling, general and administrative expenses are estimated to be 3.1% of revenue. Research and development costs $10.5 million in the fiscal quarter, intangible amortization is expected to be approximately $5 million, stock-based compensation $20 million, interest expense of $26 million in the third fiscal quarter. Based upon the current estimates of production, the tax rate on core operating income is expected to be approximately 17% for the year. Our capital expenditures are estimated to be $100 million in the quarter. The majority of this expenditure is associated with investments, Diversified Manufacturing Services and Enterprise & Infrastructure segments to support ongoing multi-quarter program runs. At this point, I shall hand the call over to Tim Main.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Forbes. Please turn to Slide 15. The first half of fiscal 2011 has been a great start to the full fiscal year. Revenues increased 31% year-over-year and a little over $8 billion. All three business segments that we report today, Diversified Man
componenttext:
Thank you, Forbes. Please turn to Slide 15. The first half of fiscal 2011 has been a great start to the full fiscal year. Revenues increased 31% year-over-year and a little over $8 billion. All three business segments that we report today, Diversified Manufacturing Services, High Velocity and Enterprise & Infrastructure are exceeding their long-term growth targets, particularly in Diversified Manufacturing Services, the most recent quarter grew 47% year-over-year. We're particularly happy by the fact that Diversified Manufacturing Services has increased to 35% of our overall business. That's from 30% about a year ago. So a very rapid growth in this area and increasing the richness of our portfolio mix. Enterprise & Infrastructure is resuming its growth rate and again, we'll likely exceed our long-term targets this year. The new wins are improving the diversification of this segment. I'll talk about that in a few moments. High velocity, we were challenged in fiscal '10 to drive operating margins to the targeted range of 2% to 2.5% and we now have two consecutive quarters that High Velocity area performed within the long-term targeted range. And we're very happy. Forbes and I are both pleased to report that free cash flow in the first half of this year is significantly above where it was in the first half of fiscal '10. Cash flow from operations in the most recent quarter $450 million, which is a pretty good performance. 
Turning to Slide 16, please, to recap Diversified Manufacturing Services. In the second fiscal quarter, we enjoyed 47% growth over the same period in fiscal 2010. 2011 growth is very likely to exceed our long-term growth target of 20% to 30%. Operating margin remains in the targeted range of 6% to 8% and we're seeing continued growth with guidance of 6% sequential growth in terms of our guidance in Q3. So, very pleased with performance in Diversified Manufacturing Services. On Page 17, Enterprise & Infrastructure is starting to demonstrate significant growth and we enjoyed 19% year-over-year growth in our second fiscal quarter. Operating margins continue to be at the high end of our targeted range of 4% to 4.5%, actually exceeded that margin in our second fiscal quarter and expectations are that we'll continue to operate within that range. We're seeing an increase in contribution of business mix from our storage and telecommunications sector. In fact, we would look for this storage and telecommunications portion of Enterprise & Infrastructure to grow to as high as 70% of the overall sector's business combined with second half of the year. And expect 8% sequential growth in fiscal Q3. So very, very strong growth there based on some new business wins in the targeted areas particularly Telecommunications and storage. 
Turning to Slide 18, please. In high velocity, we did see 27% year-over-year growth, operating margins at 2% are within the range, so for consecutive two quarters of being within the targeted range of 2% to 2.5%. And we're particularly happy with that performance given that our second fiscal quarter is typically a very poor quarter because of the seasonal down and going through a 15% sequential decline and being able to maintain operating margins at 2% and within the range is I think underscores our ability to run the full fiscal year within our targeted long-term range. Expect the second half to show consistent results with the first half and forecasting guidance of 2% to 3% sequential growth rate. 
So taking that all into account, we turn to Slide 19 please. This provides a look at our portfolio in growth, mix and how we look at the second half of the year. Hopefully, will help you out how to characterize the second half of the year relative to the first half. Our first-half actual results are a little over $8 billion, and taking the midpoint of our guidance in the third quarter and applying our long-term growth rates to the fourth fiscal quarter, with a resulting second half revenue level of $8.4 billion. This is consistent with the chart that we reviewed in the last quarter's conference call. Just helping you build a model for this year. That result in a full fiscal year of about $16.4 billion. I think it's interesting to note that if we applied the long-term growth targets to that $16.4 billion, 5% to 10% in high velocity and Enterprise & Infrastructure, 20% to 30% in Diversified Manufacturing Services, and based on the business mix we'll have at the end of this fiscal year, the company would reach $20 billion revenue level by fiscal 2013. So we're very happy to be moving in that direction and seeing significant growth in Diversified Manufacturing Services in particular. Turning to Slide 20, please. Our business transformation is well underway and I think showing up in the results. The chart on the right depicts our core operating margin, our core EBITDA margin and tracking that from fiscal '09 through the first half of fiscal 2011, an over 200 basis point improvement in both metrics and a very significant growth year-over-year. Very stressing a great deal on customer service and operational performance. Some of the improvement in margins, particularly from the '09 levels that was due to growth in the business of scale and some of it is due to portfolio mix but a significant part of the improvement in margins is due to really focusing on operational excellence, lean manufacturing and higher levels of productivity. We continue to focus on differentiated services and capabilities, particularly in targeted markets like Healthcare & Life Sciences and other areas of Diversified Manufacturing Services. And we see a growing scale, an advancing scare in targeted markets, which tends to be a virtuous cycle of lower costs, greater capabilities and greater share. 
Turning to Slide 21, please. Kind of recap near term, our challenges and opportunities, clearly the near-term challenges, one significant near-term challenge could be the significant potential for near-term supply disruptions due to the natural disaster in Japan. Right now, it's too early to accurately assess the impact to supply. We're working very closely with our suppliers and customers to mitigate any potential impact. Information, we are now in the 11th day since the tragic event took place. I think you should appreciate that some suppliers are simply scrambling to get there employees back to work, determine if and what level of damage has been done to their operations and when they can resume supply. Information is coming in rapidly and we are getting better information. But again, it's too early to accurately assess what this might do to our results in the third fiscal quarter. We thought the best thing for us to do was to give you an honest appraisal using our conventional, conservative guidance. Gives as we can of the shape and the health of the business today, excluding the potential impact that this might have. We'll be baking that just to talk about the Q&A session today, we will not be making any specific comments regarding particular customers or suppliers. I know you're very interested to know what suppliers might be most impacted, what business sectors might be most impacted, what customers might be to suffer the highest level of consequence. That is completely speculative at this point. There's no reason for us to think that Jabil's experience, if there is significant supply chain disruption, in our experience would be any different than anybody else in the electronics industry, no better and no worse. In fact, I think our diversification probably helps us in that regard. And we're not in a position to predict or help you predict what areas of the industry may be least affected or most affected. So we will have no responses to these specific questions in that regard. 
Second near-term challenge in Italy and France, we're working on sustainable profitable business plan. The impact of margins will be minimal and this was the typical decision that we made on behalf of the significant strategic customers, as well as protecting our reputation within the communities that we do business. I think it provides a significant opportunity for us though, to differentiate Jabil's customer service during a period of high stress, both in terms of acquiring sites that were struggling on behalf of strategic customers, as well as proactively working with our customers and suppliers to mitigate, minimize any supply chain disruption due to the events in Japan. I think it's an opportunity for Jabil to use its skilled resources in the area of component engineering and design resources, as well as our global supply chain management capabilities, particularly those capabilities in Asia. Jabil's also well capitalized to support customers during this period of high stress and we think it's a great reason for the customers that we serve to do business with. Our scale well capitalized and well-funded companies like Jabil over other players in the history that may not be as well positioned to support them during this period of high stress. We take this opportunity to point to our, support customers and pursuant to that, build market share and scale in targeted markets. Our growth in Diversified Manufacturing Services is exceeding our long-term targets and we're building share in Enterprise infrastructure and very gratified by that. So in summary, there are some near-term challenges. There's no reason to think that those near-term challenges will be extended at any time. The permanent challenge, in fact, Jabil has operated and reallocated component markets many times, in my experience at Jabil, and there'll be short-term disruptions, may or may not be severe. We don't know at this point. They are temporary descriptions and there's no reason to think that it will be any better or worse for Jabil and no reason to think that it will extend beyond the next quarter or two. So it's great opportunity for Jabil to differentiate ourselves with customers and the industry and to continue to grow on target markets. And our long-term strategic is on track. We're very pleased with our progress.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Patrick, we are ready to enter the question-and-answer session.
componenttext: Thanks, Tim. Patrick, we are ready to enter the question-and-answer session.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our first question comes from Craig Hettenbach with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our first question comes from Craig Hettenbach with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, just starting with the European operations that were reacquired and I understand that you said there's minimal impact to margins, is there any precedence in terms of prior actions you've done to help improve profitability and things you can point to
componenttext: Tim, just starting with the European operations that were reacquired and I understand that you said there's minimal impact to margins, is there any precedence in terms of prior actions you've done to help improve profitability and things you can point to that as you get those, that business up and running again, that you can drive some improvement?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's timing. Let me talk about first the actions that we take and then maybe some experiences that might be instructive. In the short term, the first things that we can do are focused on productivity and cost reduction within the sites themselves and w
componenttext: There's timing. Let me talk about first the actions that we take and then maybe some experiences that might be instructive. In the short term, the first things that we can do are focused on productivity and cost reduction within the sites themselves and we'll be working on that diligently, immediately. Secondly, is to make sure that the present customers in the sites are well served and hopefully enhance those relationships in order to give them confidence that we cannot always supply their current requirements but also potentially expand the business. Thirdly, if you look at the unique characteristics of the sites and develop a business plan that is sustainable and target customers and markets that can support the cost structure and take advantage of any unique capabilities that the sites might have. What our experience for Jabil is our U.S. operations today are profitable. I believe every single site in the United States is profitable. So even through we went through a period of retrenchment in the U.S., we closed a site in Massachusetts, by working on middle market accounts aggressively and we've been working on things like MPI services and plans like Michigan and really working in healthcare and areas of the business that need a U.S. presence, that actually developed a pretty robust and profitable business here in the U.S. We decided to forgo that opportunity in Europe because the market is a little bit different, a little more challenging to make those things work in Western Europe but now that we own the sites again, we're going to have revisit all of those plans and really aggressively go after it. Initially, short-term it's cost reduction, the current customers and then longer-term over the next three, four, five quarters it's really working diligently on new markets for the sites.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: If I can follow up on the tablet space, just if you can go over the strategy there and really how Green Point fits into that?
componenttext: If I can follow up on the tablet space, just if you can go over the strategy there and really how Green Point fits into that?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say that we have a separate strategy for tablets. We do business with some of the best smartphone companies in the world today and I think the unique capabilities of our Materials Technology Group at Jabil Green Point and their ability to work
componenttext: I wouldn't say that we have a separate strategy for tablets. We do business with some of the best smartphone companies in the world today and I think the unique capabilities of our Materials Technology Group at Jabil Green Point and their ability to work with new materials, a combination of materials like glass and metals and plastics and other alternative materials, these are the types of things that tablet makers and smartphone makers are very, very interested in. So I think that our growth in smartphones and tablets will come together and continue to be pretty robust for the next few years.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Last one, on the HVS business, Forbes. Nice to see the profitability within range. Does that change at all the view there? I know the strategy is focused on improving profitability and inventory turns. Will that remain the case or now that you're within t
componenttext: Last one, on the HVS business, Forbes. Nice to see the profitability within range. Does that change at all the view there? I know the strategy is focused on improving profitability and inventory turns. Will that remain the case or now that you're within the range, is it possible you might get a little bit more aggressive there or not in terms of revenue growth?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think, Craig, at this juncture, we're at the low end of the range of this quarter, which is very gratifying in a sequentially seasonally down revenue. So still somewhat to do there, keeping that 2%, 2.5 range. We anticipate that in the back half of the
componenttext: I think, Craig, at this juncture, we're at the low end of the range of this quarter, which is very gratifying in a sequentially seasonally down revenue. So still somewhat to do there, keeping that 2%, 2.5 range. We anticipate that in the back half of the year. But we'll view these opportunities on their own merit as they come to us. So what I would comment is our strategy around diversification has not changed. We are hitting all these targets and the range targets for each of our three segments. We're still driving towards our goal of Diversified Manufacturing Services business 50% of the overall revenue stream longer term. That hasn't changed and we will continue to focus on driving more margin across each of these segments.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's shown a little bit more growth than you might expect over the last couple of quarters but please appreciate that for the customers that we have at High Velocity, we are an attractive choice for them and we need to support their requirements. We need
componenttext: It's shown a little bit more growth than you might expect over the last couple of quarters but please appreciate that for the customers that we have at High Velocity, we are an attractive choice for them and we need to support their requirements. We need customers in that area to grow. We're growing with them but that is not an area that we're targeting a lot of new business development activity.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Louis Miscioscia from Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Louis Miscioscia from Collins Stewart.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe if you could just talk about R&D, SG&A and the tax rate. They all came in lower than I guess what our expectations were, which is obviously it was a good thing. Why was that the case? Can you talk about the sustainability of that for the rest of the
componenttext: Maybe if you could just talk about R&D, SG&A and the tax rate. They all came in lower than I guess what our expectations were, which is obviously it was a good thing. Why was that the case? Can you talk about the sustainability of that for the rest of the year?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of SG&A, it is marginally more. I think we've done a really good job over the last four or five quarters of leveraging that SG&A base and $120 million a year that quarter. Looking forward, you're going to see that come up a little bit, guid
componenttext: Sure. In terms of SG&A, it is marginally more. I think we've done a really good job over the last four or five quarters of leveraging that SG&A base and $120 million a year that quarter. Looking forward, you're going to see that come up a little bit, guidance next quarter is up 3.1%, so consistent with Q2. What that does is add about $6 million of expense there, $4 million fully paid to the plants in France and Italy and a little bit of room for growth there to support the continuing growth across our Enterprise. R&D, nothing in particular there. We've droid various activities and programs. I think as you know, design can be a little bit more challenging to predict exactly where some of these programs launch and finish. So nothing in particular there and we'll continue to see that as we move forward. In terms of the tax rate, that came in lower than we expected and that's really being driven by the sources of revenue and income on a geographic basis. So we'd expect that given what we see today as we move forward, 17% as we move forward to the balance of this fiscal year. I would drive your attention to we still have some high-quality in various geographies in Asia and the impact of operations but until achieve our 17% as we move forward.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: A follow up to '10. The fact that you moved the $20 billion target in a year. Could you just remind us what the long-term growth targets is? I think that it's obviously you mentioned earlier 20% to 30% for diversified and I believe 5% to 10% for Enterpris
componenttext: A follow up to '10. The fact that you moved the $20 billion target in a year. Could you just remind us what the long-term growth targets is? I think that it's obviously you mentioned earlier 20% to 30% for diversified and I believe 5% to 10% for Enterprise but you also 5% to 10% for high velocity or do you expect that to be flat? Because if there is growth there, then obviously it seems like the number could even be higher.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: The long-term target is 5% to 10%, which really represents kind of a secular growth rate with the existing customer base and I think there's a big thing in terms of kind of average that out with the current mix of business, it results in a 13% to 15% year
componenttext: The long-term target is 5% to 10%, which really represents kind of a secular growth rate with the existing customer base and I think there's a big thing in terms of kind of average that out with the current mix of business, it results in a 13% to 15% year-over-year growth rate. And last quarter, I think we indicated that based on those growth targets, we were likely to hit a $20 billion or more revenue level by fiscal 2014, fiscal 2015. If the change is that we're doing a heck of a lot better this year and we're going to significantly exceed those long-term growth rates in all three segments. Therefore, we're really kind of pulling in the day at which now that the year in which we were likely to hit a $20 billion run rate. So it's not guidance. It's simply applying the logic of what our long-term growth trajectory is to our current state of affairs and taking a look at what this business might look like in a couple of years if we were able to achieve those aspirations.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Amit Daryanani from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Amit Daryanani from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, on the DMS margins, can you just talk about what drove that down sequentially, specially given that Specialized Services were actually up in revenues? And as you get to the back half of the year, should we expect those margins getting
componenttext: Two questions. One, on the DMS margins, can you just talk about what drove that down sequentially, specially given that Specialized Services were actually up in revenues? And as you get to the back half of the year, should we expect those margins getting back to the 7% at the midpoint of your long-term targets?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the second part of that question first. We do expect margins to rebound somewhat in the second half of the year in terms of the performance in Q2. Really, it's a range, it 6% to 8%. We're actually pleased that continues in that range and I thi
componenttext: I'll answer the second part of that question first. We do expect margins to rebound somewhat in the second half of the year in terms of the performance in Q2. Really, it's a range, it 6% to 8%. We're actually pleased that continues in that range and I think you can see some variation, in particularly Diversified Manufacturing Services and variation plus or minus quarter to quarter based on levels of production and what we might be doing in terms of new product launches, etc. In terms of the last quarter, we did have a little weakness in semiconductor capital equipment's. That is a little bit less than anticipated and making investments, particularly in Specialized Services to support continued growth in Specialized Services in the second half of the year. So if you take a look at where the margins were in the second quarter versus the midpoint, it's about $10 million of additional income and you consider $3 million or $4 million in semi cap and some of the other areas of Instrumentation, a little bit weaker in Q2 with the balance of it being expenses and investments to support more aggressive ramp of production in the second half of the year. So we'd expect that picture to brighten a bit in Q3 and Q4.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: So just to clarify, on the pre-European side, I think you had about $60 million or so in revenues and losses which I expect on a quarterly basis, is that accurate?
componenttext: So just to clarify, on the pre-European side, I think you had about $60 million or so in revenues and losses which I expect on a quarterly basis, is that accurate?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: About 1.5% of next quarter's midpoint of guidance, right about $60 million of revenue. And it is a range of losses $5 million to $10 million, depending on the level of performance and our ability to structure our long-term business plans.
componenttext: About 1.5% of next quarter's midpoint of guidance, right about $60 million of revenue. And it is a range of losses $5 million to $10 million, depending on the level of performance and our ability to structure our long-term business plans.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, first question for you. I just wanted to understand what exactly is embedded in your assumptions for the guidance for next quarter with respect to Japan? Is your guidance basically predicated on business that you're seeing today or do you sort of may
componenttext: Tim, first question for you. I just wanted to understand what exactly is embedded in your assumptions for the guidance for next quarter with respect to Japan? Is your guidance basically predicated on business that you're seeing today or do you sort of maybe factor in some conservatism just given some of the uncertainty around Japan?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: To be very sanitary about this, we are not baking in significant supply disruptions from Japan. Our normal processes do take a fairly conservative you of our forward-looking guidance. And if you look at the last I believe that we've operated or exceeded t
componenttext: To be very sanitary about this, we are not baking in significant supply disruptions from Japan. Our normal processes do take a fairly conservative you of our forward-looking guidance. And if you look at the last I believe that we've operated or exceeded the high end of our revenue range in six of the last seven quarters. So that should give you an idea that we would typically take a fairly conservative view of revenue guidance to begin with. So there are inconceivable scenarios where the impact from Japan would be very minimal or slight and our guidance accommodates that impact. It can also be conceivable that impacted the very significant in which case we would suffer a greater deal than what's anticipated. So we are taking our normal conventional typical conservative view on revenue guidance, not baking in anything specific to Japan. It doesn't mean that with some disruption, we might not be able to range to begin with or in the end. But it's kind of the way we look at it.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: One follow up. The segments in the quarter, president and enterprise infrastructure came in significantly stronger. I think your expectations, frankly than ours, probably doesn't mean much. But just wanted to understand the puts and takes, E&I project com
componenttext: One follow up. The segments in the quarter, president and enterprise infrastructure came in significantly stronger. I think your expectations, frankly than ours, probably doesn't mean much. But just wanted to understand the puts and takes, E&I project coming in the stronger than anticipated. I think it's consumer made High Velocity Systems slightly weaker. Pity you say maybe what you're seeing there with respect event patterns, demand trends and may be something new design that you talked about in E&I project?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: This looks pretty good. Overall demand looks pretty good. I think we continue to see a continuing recovery in North America. So pretty good color end demand. And our Enterprise & Infrastructure, some of the new business wins are particularly strong in the
componenttext: This looks pretty good. Overall demand looks pretty good. I think we continue to see a continuing recovery in North America. So pretty good color end demand. And our Enterprise & Infrastructure, some of the new business wins are particularly strong in the wireless infrastructure area, particularly in emerging markets and secondarily gaining share in new programs in the storage market. So those two parts of the Enterprise infrastructure business are showing very robust activity right now.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011

componenttext: And then on high velocity, any comments there?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I mean it came in a little bit weaker like $20 million, $25 million weaker than the guidance we provided you with. That business is by nature handsets, set-top boxes and Printing products in there. At the very nature, it is a volatile business, it's c
componenttext: No, I mean it came in a little bit weaker like $20 million, $25 million weaker than the guidance we provided you with. That business is by nature handsets, set-top boxes and Printing products in there. At the very nature, it is a volatile business, it's consumer business. Slightly weaker $20 million, $25 million. Nothing that jumps out there. Really around that volatility. I think it's pretty close to our expectations.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Brian Alexander from Raymond James.
componenttext: The next question comes from Brian Alexander from Raymond James.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Business for built. I just wanted to touch on the VMS growth. We've seen meaningful growth there for the past several quarters but we haven't seen any significant gross margin expansion. Is this a result of the CapEx you've been making over the past four
componenttext: Business for built. I just wanted to touch on the VMS growth. We've seen meaningful growth there for the past several quarters but we haven't seen any significant gross margin expansion. Is this a result of the CapEx you've been making over the past four quarters, have been above $100 million? And can you discuss that those investments have been dealing with giving the results of expected?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a small correction. Operating margin, not gross margin. Because we report operating margins in this area.
componenttext: Just a small correction. Operating margin, not gross margin. Because we report operating margins in this area.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: To answer the question, yes, we have a great leverage in our SG&A and it was around investments. Specialized Services. There is some element of lag in terms of new investments, we're making until we get product launch up and running. So some lag there, ma
componenttext: To answer the question, yes, we have a great leverage in our SG&A and it was around investments. Specialized Services. There is some element of lag in terms of new investments, we're making until we get product launch up and running. So some lag there, maybe a quarter or two. As you've said, we have capital investments. Majority of the investments $30 million plus last quarter has been directed towards diversified manufacturer service and in particular, our Specialized Services arena. We continue to see that as we move forward into Q3. But we would expect to see margins gross margins expansion as we move into the back half of this fiscal year.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I want to go back to this topic. There's a reason that we don't provide guidance on the gross margin basis because forward the last 10 years and we've said we don't really regard that as a meaningful metric for us. There is significant change business
componenttext: And I want to go back to this topic. There's a reason that we don't provide guidance on the gross margin basis because forward the last 10 years and we've said we don't really regard that as a meaningful metric for us. There is significant change business-to-business, program to program, customer to customer in terms of the material content of revenue stream and that's really the primary determinative of gross margin. We're really focused on operating margin as diversified manufacturing services increased from 30% to 35% of our operating margins and had followed through 3.7% to 4.4% for the first half of this year. So very significant improvement in the operating performance of the business. Really, gross margin is not a metric that we track. We don't regard it as significantly meaningful.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Overall, I think we standby from the targets we've given. Think previously talked about a 25%, 35% free cash flow number as EBITDA. That base of business that we grow long-term by 15% to 20%. Of course we're not giving guidance for our fourth quarter. I t
componenttext: Overall, I think we standby from the targets we've given. Think previously talked about a 25%, 35% free cash flow number as EBITDA. That base of business that we grow long-term by 15% to 20%. Of course we're not giving guidance for our fourth quarter. I think there's opportunity that we would certainly grow beyond the high end of that long-term target this fiscal year given the first half performance and our Q2 guidance. On an overall basis, I think there is certainly an opportunity to drive free cash flow for at about a 20% level. If one backs into the math there on a consistent growth rate, 10% to 15%. That would equate to that 30% ratio. To summarize, I think there's opportunity here to produce free cash flow this fiscal year, right about 20% of overall EBITDA.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: It would take a very significant deterioration in inventory turn, which is really the only difference between the DMS area working capital intensive than the other areas of the business. It would take a significant deterioration in the company's inventory
componenttext: It would take a very significant deterioration in inventory turn, which is really the only difference between the DMS area working capital intensive than the other areas of the business. It would take a significant deterioration in the company's inventory turns overall to jeopardize our performance in free cash flow and the expectations of free cash flow. We just don't see that happening.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Fox from CLSC.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of components, the markets since the fourth quarter of 2010 as component supply and capacity has really caught up with demand, lead times have been coming in and it's been turning into more of a buyer's market than a seller's market. I think that
componenttext: In terms of components, the markets since the fourth quarter of 2010 as component supply and capacity has really caught up with demand, lead times have been coming in and it's been turning into more of a buyer's market than a seller's market. I think that's pretty well-known out there and pretty well covered . In terms of specific equipment, nothing that we think will pace our business. There are certain types of equipment that lead times are a little bit difficult but nothing that would place our business below our expectations. And the third part of the question was about additional investments in DMS, I think?

componenttextpreview: Payback investments.
componenttext: Payback investments.

componenttext: Payback periods whether DMS would start to slow down to CapEx.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think particularly in the Materials Technology Group, there were some significant investments made in 2010 and success of that investment and growing revenue there, there have been some additional investments. I would think that that will start to slow
componenttext: I think particularly in the Materials Technology Group, there were some significant investments made in 2010 and success of that investment and growing revenue there, there have been some additional investments. I would think that that will start to slow down, maybe certainly in fiscal 2012. I looking at CapEx rate of $100 million a quarter kind of CapEx rate. You're probably likely to see that the next couple of quarters. As we absorb that very rapid growth, I think that rate will start to slow down a bit. And the payback periods are relatively conventional and nothing out of the ordinary for us.

componenttext: Tim, can you talk about the new areas, perhaps that you've been able to leverage Green Point capabilities outside of high velocity? And can you give us some sense of the relative, is there a mix or growth rate between high velocity and perhaps Enterprise & Infrastructure or specifically for Green Point over there?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to be clear, the Jabil Green Point is in the Diversified Manufacturing Services area. You're probably saying is businesses outside of the mobile Internet business and we do have some of the new capabilities in applied ingenuity and innovation capabil
componenttext: Just to be clear, the Jabil Green Point is in the Diversified Manufacturing Services area. You're probably saying is businesses outside of the mobile Internet business and we do have some of the new capabilities in applied ingenuity and innovation capabilities that Jabil Green Point directed towards our healthcare business and life sciences business. We think that will be very beneficial over the next few years. And helps to differentiate Jabil solutions relative to other competitors and providers in our space. That said, that slope rate is not going to be nearly as rapid as their core businesses today. I think they will start to pay dividends already. There are new program wins we are winning because of their capability today. And we've become more materials our results in 2012 and 2013 as we continue to provide integration. It wasn't clear, the question about Enterprise & Infrastructure, though, how that's related? Maybe you could repeat that part of your question.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: It will continue to be reported in diversified manufacturing services. In the areas of differentiation beyond the mobile Internet are also in diversified manufacturing services like healthcare and Instrumentation and Industrial & Clean Tech. Diversificati
componenttext: It will continue to be reported in diversified manufacturing services. In the areas of differentiation beyond the mobile Internet are also in diversified manufacturing services like healthcare and Instrumentation and Industrial & Clean Tech. Diversification of their capabilities for mobile Internet were in addition to the mobile Internet products that they've built today are in those two business areas specifically.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: We made significant investments in fiscal 2010 that investment has continued in 2011 as success in that area has proven out. So I have to be -- I really can't answer specific questions about specific investments because that can get tied directly to custo
componenttext: We made significant investments in fiscal 2010 that investment has continued in 2011 as success in that area has proven out. So I have to be -- I really can't answer specific questions about specific investments because that can get tied directly to customers and certain programs and I'm really not at liberty to do that.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Tim, you noted that you really can't talk a whole lot about Japan but from a modification of impact or customer perspective but when do you think you'll have enough information? Should we be expecting more of a mid-quarter update from you?
componenttext: And Tim, you noted that you really can't talk a whole lot about Japan but from a modification of impact or customer perspective but when do you think you'll have enough information? Should we be expecting more of a mid-quarter update from you?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: We do not intend to provide any mid-quarter updates and information continues to come in, it bees discreet and granular. But we're not sure -- the behavior in the industry is such that people scramble like crazy. And you may not know until very late in th
componenttext: We do not intend to provide any mid-quarter updates and information continues to come in, it bees discreet and granular. But we're not sure -- the behavior in the industry is such that people scramble like crazy. And you may not know until very late in the game and at any particular moment when a certain component will break free or design engineers have come up with a design around or an alternative component that requires some qualification and you maybe thinking that there's a significant impact the business and then the qualification takes place at an alternative component. Then suddenly, you're able to run 24/7 and recover those deliveries. So it's really difficult even over the course of the quarter to provide any type of quantification. So I think, I look at where this happened and the people of Japan have shown culturally and historically have shown tremendous resilience and I've got a lot of friends in Japan and our own employees and gosh, if there's a group on the planet that says we'll work 24 hours a day to recover schedules and capabilities on behalf of customers, these folks will do it. It's likely to be in certain areas and the scramble all quarter. We just can't quantify that impact. It would be almost reckless for us to predict when we'd be able to provide any further guidance.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just might also add though, there's no reason to think -- if it ends up being an enormous impact, it's going to be an enormous impact for everybody. There's no reason to think that the impact that Jabil is going to be hitting different than anyone else'
componenttext: I just might also add though, there's no reason to think -- if it ends up being an enormous impact, it's going to be an enormous impact for everybody. There's no reason to think that the impact that Jabil is going to be hitting different than anyone else's. And if the impact seems to be minimal and all the major OEMs in the world seems to be running at about the levels, there's no reason to think that we will be a heck of a lot different than that either. So our diversification, our capabilities, large Global Supply Chain strength, the ability to proactively work with customers and potentially proactively help our smaller customers with workarounds and different components I think are significant assets to Jabil and significant capabilities that will help us. I think -- I don't think that investors should think there's anything unique about Jabil that would expose us to risk that aren't any different than the industry at large.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: One last one for me. This might be too premature but any early indications of increased activity levels in Clean Tech after this disaster in Japan?
componenttext: One last one for me. This might be too premature but any early indications of increased activity levels in Clean Tech after this disaster in Japan?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I won't talk so far. We'll see. Renewable energy, the world goes through cycles on these kinds of things and we've seen it goes up and down. I would think that renewable energy will enjoy a good cycle after this.
componenttext: I won't talk so far. We'll see. Renewable energy, the world goes through cycles on these kinds of things and we've seen it goes up and down. I would think that renewable energy will enjoy a good cycle after this.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Sherri Scribner of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Sherri Scribner of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that you're gaining share in the wireless infrastructure and the storage segments for E&I. Is that with new customers or is that with existing customers generally?
componenttext: You mentioned that you're gaining share in the wireless infrastructure and the storage segments for E&I. Is that with new customers or is that with existing customers generally?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Really, I hate to use the term market share gains. It's a little bit of a misnomer. I mean we have enjoyed some new business wins ramping up in the mass production and it's principally with existing customers.
componenttext: Really, I hate to use the term market share gains. It's a little bit of a misnomer. I mean we have enjoyed some new business wins ramping up in the mass production and it's principally with existing customers.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then are there any other areas of the business, I assume in DMS where you're seeing that you're gaining share whether it's new customers or existing customers that you emphasize?
componenttext: And then are there any other areas of the business, I assume in DMS where you're seeing that you're gaining share whether it's new customers or existing customers that you emphasize?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: The interesting thing about DMS, Sherri is the secular trend to outsource the design manufacture and support of Healthcare & Instrumentation, Clean Tech and Industrial Products is increasing a great deal. So the penetration rate of our industry into that
componenttext: The interesting thing about DMS, Sherri is the secular trend to outsource the design manufacture and support of Healthcare & Instrumentation, Clean Tech and Industrial Products is increasing a great deal. So the penetration rate of our industry into that $500 billion available market is really only in the 10% to 15% range. So market share is much less of an issue in that area. it's really a growing market, a rapidly growing market and the companies that can differentiate their capabilities will enjoy a greater portion of that overall market growth and really, we're in a great position to do is to leverage our capabilities and unique differentiators that we have to garner more of the growth that's flooding into the marketplace and really put up strong numbers over the next few years.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the secular trend outsourcing there, would you say that trend is driving the 20% to 30% growth that you expect in that segment or does that 20% to 30% include some share gains that you think you'll get above and beyond other players?
componenttext: So the secular trend outsourcing there, would you say that trend is driving the 20% to 30% growth that you expect in that segment or does that 20% to 30% include some share gains that you think you'll get above and beyond other players?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's really principally, that 20% to 30% is principally about the growth of the market and our ability to develop a very strong franchise in that growing market. That's much, much less about market share.
componenttext: It's really principally, that 20% to 30% is principally about the growth of the market and our ability to develop a very strong franchise in that growing market. That's much, much less about market share.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the investments you're making in DMS for the second half of the year, are those for new programs or with existing customers or are those for new programs with the new customers generally?
componenttext: And then the investments you're making in DMS for the second half of the year, are those for new programs or with existing customers or are those for new programs with the new customers generally?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: The Healthcare & Life Science area has been a pretty robust new business pipeline, so there will be some investments there to support programs. And healthcare programs ramp very slowly, but will contribute more in 2012 and 2011 but we will see that busine
componenttext: The Healthcare & Life Science area has been a pretty robust new business pipeline, so there will be some investments there to support programs. And healthcare programs ramp very slowly, but will contribute more in 2012 and 2011 but we will see that business area start to growth again in the second half of the year. And then continued investment with existing customers.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: In addition, our markets, there's some nice new wins there. We will be making some investments there.
componenttext: In addition, our markets, there's some nice new wins there. We will be making some investments there.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from Jim Suva from Citi.
componenttext: Your final question comes from Jim Suva from Citi.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a detailed question that I'll ask first so then I can follow up with the other one while you look into this. I'm referring to Slide #19 and that's entitled growth and improving portfolio mix. There's four charts there. I actually have a few investo
componenttext: I have a detailed question that I'll ask first so then I can follow up with the other one while you look into this. I'm referring to Slide #19 and that's entitled growth and improving portfolio mix. There's four charts there. I actually have a few investors e-mail me some questions that maybe you can help clarify. When we look at first half of 2011 versus the second half of 2011, the green section basically more than doubles and the red section basically gets cut in third. Maybe while you look at that chart, can help us understand if that would you expect your second half 2011 total company mix to be or is that the portion of the growth that you see coming from that? With it almost looks like high velocities going to get caught and third. And then as you look at that then give us some thought, little bit of an easier is not as detailed or start specific, Tim, when you put in the CapEx last year in May and August, there was a bigger than normal CapEx ramp. Has that ramped up halfway, fully on a run rate or where we at in that stage? And was that CapEx focused on diversified services or what segment?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: The big CapEx in 2010 was directed to diversified manufacturing services. That is fully ramped up and again, because of the success in that business area, we are making your investments. In our CapEx rate, continue with $100 million for next couple of qua
componenttext: The big CapEx in 2010 was directed to diversified manufacturing services. That is fully ramped up and again, because of the success in that business area, we are making your investments. In our CapEx rate, continue with $100 million for next couple of quarters. On the depiction of the second half of 2011, that isn't necessarily an accurate depiction of this mix certainly don't mean to imply that high velocity is going to fall by half. So if you take a look at the full year 2011, there's probably a little better visual on how we would expect the year to end up. Little better performance in diversified manufacturing services and high velocity had some pretty good growth in Enterprise & Infrastructure. If you take a look at our guidance, we've got three quarters of the year kind of in the boardroom so there's no significant distortions that is going to happen in the fourth quarter. So that's kind of a book on our part. We will try to make that pictorially more accurate next quarter.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the best way to think about that picture is that it's more the additional business coming in on top, not your future business mix?
componenttext: So the best way to think about that picture is that it's more the additional business coming in on top, not your future business mix?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you could specifically probably came up with the $8.4 billion and you can do this math and we can talk about it later just to make sure we have the right numbers. So it's the actual results for the first half. And taking the midpoint of our guidan
componenttext: I think you could specifically probably came up with the $8.4 billion and you can do this math and we can talk about it later just to make sure we have the right numbers. So it's the actual results for the first half. And taking the midpoint of our guidance, we said 6% growth in diversified manufacturing services, 8% growth in Enterprise & Infrastructure and 3% for high velocity. Just extend the percentages of the business in the first half, try those sequential growth rates for the third quarter. Then for the fourth quarter, apply the midpoint of the long-term growth objectives, which is 20% to 30% in Diversified Manufacturing Services, 5% to 10% in high velocity Enterprise & Infrastructure. That's how you come up with the number.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: It shows that that's not what your future business mix will look like.
componenttext: It shows that that's not what your future business mix will look like.

componenttext: That's right.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
