headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Lasey and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the third quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Beth Walters, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Lasey and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the third quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Beth Walters, you may begin your conference.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to our third quarter of fiscal 2011 earnings call. Joining me on the call today are President and CEO, Tim Main; and our Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander. This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to our third quarter of fiscal 2011 earnings call. Joining me on the call today are President and CEO, Tim Main; and our Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander. This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, jabil.com, in the Investors section. Our third quarter press release and corresponding webcast and slides are also available on our website. On those slides, you will find the financial information that we cover during this conference call. We ask that you follow our presentation of the slides in the website beginning with Slide 2 now. 
During this conference call, we will be making forward-looking statements, including those regarding the anticipated outlook for our business, our currently expected third quarter of fiscal 2011 revenue and earnings results, our long-term outlook for the company and improvements in our operational efficiencies and financial performance. These statements are based on current expectations, forecasts and assumptions involving risks and uncertainties that could cause actual outcomes and results to differ materially. An extensive list of these risks and uncertainties are identified in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2010, on filing subsequent reports on Form 10-Q and Form 8-K and our other securities filings. Jabil disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. Today's call will begin with our third quarter results, some comments and highlights from Forbes Alexander on the results, as well as guidance on our fourth quarter of fiscal 2011. Tim Main will then follow with some macro environment and Jabil-specific comments about our performance, our motto and our current outlook. We will then open it up to questions for all call attendees. I'll now turn the call over to Forbes.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Beth, and good morning, everyone. I'll ask you to refer to Slides 3 and 4. Net revenue for the third quarter was $4.2 billion, an increase of 22.3% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $152.5 million. This compares to $96.5 mill
componenttext:
Thank you, Beth, and good morning, everyone. I'll ask you to refer to Slides 3 and 4. Net revenue for the third quarter was $4.2 billion, an increase of 22.3% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $152.5 million. This compares to $96.5 million of GAAP operating income from revenues of $3.5 billion for the same period in the prior year. Core operating income, excluding amortization of intangibles and stock-based compensation, increased 34.8% to $177.8 million and represents 4.2% revenue. This compares to $131.9 million or 3.8% for the same period in the prior year. On a sequential basis, revenue increased 7.6% in the third quarter, while core operating income increased 5.6%. Core diluted earnings per share were $0.58, an increase of 45% over the prior year. 
Please refer to slides 5 and 6 where for mix and core operating income in each of our segments for the third fiscal quarter. I would also like to remind you that the third fiscal quarter results include a full quarter results from operations related to the sites we acquired in France and Italy late last quarter. On a comparable sequential basis, these sites impacted overall gross margin negatively by approximately 15 basis points and core operating income negatively by 20 basis points in the quarter. 
Let's turn to our segments. Our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment grew 9.4% sequentially. On a yearly basis, this segment grew 44%. Revenue was approximately $1.5 billion, representing 36% total company revenue in the third quarter. Core operating income expanded sequentially by 10 basis points to 6.2% in the quarter. The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment grew 11.8% sequentially. On a yearly basis, the segment grew by 15.5%. Revenue was approximately $1.4 billion and represented 33% of total company revenues in the third quarter. Core operating income was 3.9% of revenue. This segment includes the results of operations of the sites we acquired in France and Italy, which had a negative impact of 50 basis points on core operating in this segment. These operating returns, the segment remains at the high end of our overall operating margin target. The High Velocity segment increased 1.7% sequentially. On a yearly basis, this segment grew by 10%. Revenue was approximately $1.3 billion, representing 31% of total company revenue in the third quarter. The core operating income was 2.2% of revenue, an expansion of 20 basis points. Our top 10 customers in the quarter accounted for approximately 63% of our revenue. 
And now I'll ask you to refer to slides 7, 8 and 9, which accompany my commentary on elements of our third quarter operating and balance sheet performance. Selling, general and administrative expenses were $134.1 million, and represent 3.2% of revenue. Part of the $12 million sequential increase is associated with the operations we acquired in France and Italy. The balance of costs represent faster than we anticipated to support margin growth across our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment. Research and development costs were $6.5 million in the quarter. Intangibles amortization was $5.2 million and stock-based compensation was $20.1 million in the quarter. Our net interest expense for the quarter was $26 million and the tax rate on a net core operating income was 15.2%. 
Our sales cycle in the quarter was consistent with the previous quarter of 11 days, and improved by 5 days from the same period a year ago. Days in inventory decreased by 2 days while turns remained consistent at 7. Core return on invested capital for the quarter was 28.5%, cash flow from operations was $158.8 million and cash and cash equivalents were $911.1 million. There are no outstanding balances on our revolver at the end of the third quarter. 
Depreciation in the quarter was approximately $77.3 million and core EBITDA was $255.1 million or 6% of revenue. Our capital expenditures during the quarter were approximately $113.6 million as we continue to invest in infrastructure to support the targeted marketing capabilities. Approximately $71 million was associated with our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment, $21 million with Enterprise & Infrastructure, $8 million in High Velocity and $13 million in installation technology and infrastructure. We remain very well-positioned to continue to produce free cash flow within our fourth fiscal quarter and through fiscal '12. And with this in mind, we are pleased to advised that our board of directors has authorized the repurchase of up to $200 million worth of common stock during the next 12 months in open market transactions. 
I'd now like to refer to slides 10 and 11. In summary, we are pleased with the results of the third quarter and are extremely well positioned to meet the overall fiscal '11 goals. In the third quarter our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment represented 36% of company revenue versus 31% for the same period a year ago. Our overall company core operating income margins have expanded from 3.7% to 4.2% over the same period. Capital investments year-to-date and for the fourth quarter have and shall be focused in the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment. 60% for the full year's capital expenditure investment have been committed to expanding the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment, supporting our stated goals to fundamentally shift the revenue and income profile of the company to provide overall sustainable operating performance and free cash flow generation. 
I'd now like to provide you with our fourth quarter fiscal 2011 guidance and ask that you refer to Slides 13 and 14. We expect revenue in the fourth quarter on a year-over-year basis to increase by approximately 9% on the range of $4.1 billion to $4.3 billion. The Diversified Manufacturing Services segment is expected to increase by 7% sequentially, with growth across all areas of business in this segment. The Enterprise & Infrastructure group are expected to increase by 3% sequentially despite the ongoing wireless network and product ramps, and our High Velocity segment is expected to decrease 13% sequentially, solely as a result of the late new product introductions and eroding demand from a major Mobility customer. The core operating income is estimated to be in the range of $165 million to $185 million, core operating margin in the range of 4% to 4.3% and core earnings per share in the range of $0.52 to $0.60 per deleted share. Selling, general and administrative expenses are expected to remain at 2.3% revenue in the fourth quarter. We expect selling, general and industry expense to move back to 3% of revenue in fiscal 2012. Research and development costs are expected to be $7 million in the fourth quarter, and tangibles amortization approximately $5 million, stock-based compensation $20 million, finally interest expense, $26 million in the quarter. Based on the current estimates of production, the tax rate on core operating income in the fourth quarter is expected to be approximately 17%. Our capital expenditures in the fourth quarter are estimated to be approximately $100 million. As I previously noted, a majority of these expenditures associated with investments and diversified manufacturing services. At this point, I'll hand the call over to Tim Main.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Forbes. I'm referring now to Slide 15. The company is exceeding its long-term growth targets since fiscal 2011. We'll post revenue base at the midpoint of our guidance for Q4, revenue of approximately $16.4 billion, roughly a $3 billion growth
componenttext:
Thank you, Forbes. I'm referring now to Slide 15. The company is exceeding its long-term growth targets since fiscal 2011. We'll post revenue base at the midpoint of our guidance for Q4, revenue of approximately $16.4 billion, roughly a $3 billion growth rate over the previous year. About $500 million of that growth is high velocity, representing about 10% growth rate year-over-year. $800 million will come from the Enterprise & Infrastructure area, representing about an 18% growth rate year-over-year. And looking at the Diversified Manufacturing Services area, healthcare should grow year-over-year by about 31%, Industrial & Clean Tech about 18% and Specialized Services 64%, resulting in overall growth in Diversified Manufacturing Services year-over-year of $1.7 billion or 40%. We're very pleased with this performance. 
Please move to Slide 16. We this growth in Diversified Manufacturing Services in particular, the company believes it is differentiated and resulting in a much more sustainable portfolio of businesses. This chart indicates the progression of the percentage of business of the 3 business areas: High velocity, Enterprise & Infrastructure and Diversified Manufacturing Services over the course of Q1 2010, over the quarter period to the midpoint of guidance for Q4 2011. Our largest segment now and for the past couple of quarters is Diversified Manufacturing Services, which is well on its way to being 45% to 50% of our overall business. And we have a high level of confidence that this will result in a more resilient and sustainable business for our company in the future years. Please turn to Slide 17 year call that stock about diversified manufacturing services a little bit further. Now, we believe are another premium player in the Diversified Manufacturing Services. Look right now, our competitors don't put businesses this way, and we think it's a very rich diversified area for Jabil's differentiation and business model capabilities, and its 33% annual growth rates since fiscal 2009, growing to an almost $6 billion business for us in fiscal 2011. On a stand-alone basis, I think it's interesting to note that on a stand-alone basis, this would be the fastest-growing business and a top 5 player in terms of the North American EMS industry. So we're very happy with the performance of Diversified Manufacturing Services. A lot of questions about how sustainable this is and how differentiated, how can we stay in this type of growth and expectation going forward. Please turn to Slide 18. Let's talk a little bit about differentiation and Diversified Manufacturing Services. In the Materials Technology Group, I think we're uniquely differentiated in materials technology, not only helping that part of our business grow at very rapid rate, is providing excellent synergistic value to targeted markets, such as healthcare and other areas. We believe the strongest player in the Aftermarket Services with excellent depth in our capabilities and we're taking these capabilities and diversifying them into new geographies and markets. In the Healthcare & Instrumentation, we're well beyond the electronic score in healthcare. We're focused on product development and full systems and we're really focused on the high growth areas of customer healthcare. So well beyond the electronics envelope in this business area. And this happens to be a segment where a high mix, high complexity manufacturing is extremely important. And based in our business drives, our success here, we believe that our company is the premier high mix, high complexity manufacturer. Over 70% of our production is produced in quantities of less than 100 and that's for the overall business. And it's certainly much higher mix and higher complexity in the Healthcare & Instrumentation segment on its own. In Industrial & Clean Tech, we're early mover in the Clean Tech business and have broad participation in the entire investor and Clean Tech echo system and our intent is to continue to build on that strength. 
Slide 19, our number one priority as a company is to deliver excellence in customer service. We think we're making progress in that area in our operational performance. Our scale is advancing in targeted markets, believing we have differentiated services and capabilities, focus on lean and productivity allows us to continuously reduce costs to a point where our operating margins and EBITDA margins lead the industry. You can see from the chart on the right that from fiscal '09, core operating margins at 2%. This year, will run the full year fourth quarter be our fifth consecutive quarter of core operating margins above 4%. And at least, our fourth consecutive quarter EBITDA margin is above 6%. In essence, with Jabil, you're getting Tier I scale, with EBITDA margins at 200 basis points above Tier 1 bracket and operating margins that are significantly higher, 50 to 100 basis points higher than our Tier I. So Tier I scale at each player margins. 
Turning to Slide 20, companies increasing cash generation. This is very important. We believe we're in business to produce cash flow for our shareholders and we're moving through an inflection point wherein free cash is deflected and continuing increasing. This free cash flow funds CapEx, acquisitions, dividends and share repurchases and such as we've just talked about. I think it's interesting to compare the 9 months ending 5/31 2011 with the 9 months ended 5/31 2010. Cash flow from operations has increased $382 million from $142 million to $524 million. Our free cash flow has gone from a negative $6 million to a positive $226 million. We're well on our way to producing $1 billion in fiscal 2011 and this is starting to accumulate cash, which allows us to do things like share repurchases. And we continue to invest in high-growth areas of our company. 
Slide 21, the results of an improving portfolio mix, a sustainable business model based on differentiation, free cash flow is beginning to produce shareholder return metrics that I think are enviable. Our GAAP return on equity and GAAP return on invested capital are both in the mid20s very consistent with S&P 500 metrics. We do expect free cash flow this year of approximately $330 million based on the midpoint of our Q4 guidance. We will continue to pay approximately $60 million in dividends. And we are in a position really to fund up to a $200 million share repurchase at our discretion over the next year. 
Slide 22, when we look at the population of companies that can put up this type of growth in cash flow and earnings over a long period of time, I think it's interesting to compare us to Fortune 500 companies. Our company's IPO was in 1993 and since our first full year as a public company through 2010, we are one of just 5 Fortune 500 companies that have posted a 16-year company annual growth rate of 25% or better in both revenue, EBITDA and pays regular dividends. We are happy to be in this elite and record-setting group of companies and it's our intent to continue to run the business to be able to produce those types of results over the next few years. Thank you.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Matt Sheerin of Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Matt Sheerin of Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: A question on the High Velocity segment. You did guide that down. Do you expect negative leverage in kind of what operating margin you're expecting in that group? And I ask that because your margin guidance is basically flat sequentially if you look at th
componenttext: A question on the High Velocity segment. You did guide that down. Do you expect negative leverage in kind of what operating margin you're expecting in that group? And I ask that because your margin guidance is basically flat sequentially if you look at the midpoint, yet, mix shift worked in your favor with diversified manufacturing in the ENI Group growing at a faster rate. So I'm trying to figure out what kind of negative impact you're expecting from the high velocity? And as a follow on to that, as you look to the November quarter, are you expecting to see that ramp up sequentially again and will that help margins there?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of the question, in terms of the overall margins for the high velocity. So we got it down 30% sequentially. So yes, we will some impact to the margin product segment. Our target ranges 2% to 2.5% this quarter. The midpoint of that
componenttext: I'll take the first part of the question, in terms of the overall margins for the high velocity. So we got it down 30% sequentially. So yes, we will some impact to the margin product segment. Our target ranges 2% to 2.5% this quarter. The midpoint of that target. So yes, it's got to be towards the lower end, perhaps a little bit lower end there because I should point out, we are seeing some great strengths in our Diversified Manufacturing Services arena at 7% sequential growth and some nice growth in enterprise infrastructure. So you'll see expansion in terms of contribution of margin of those Diversified Manufacturing Services, Enterprise & Infrastructure and some declines in high velocity. But certainly, I expect those margins to come back as we move into Q1.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: When we look at fiscal Q1, we will be through some very significant role. Will be in a more mature stage. That is a very significant programs that are ramping in both enterprise infrastructure and in healthcare. And we do expect to see significant growth
componenttext: When we look at fiscal Q1, we will be through some very significant role. Will be in a more mature stage. That is a very significant programs that are ramping in both enterprise infrastructure and in healthcare. And we do expect to see significant growth in Q1 in Diversified Manufacturing Services, probably steady growth in enterprise infrastructure. And we don't see any reason why high velocity would not exhibit its normal seasonal pattern of high growth in fiscal Q1, excluding the impact of a major Mobility customer in the high velocity area. So we put that together and are actually very excited about the prospects for fiscal Q1 and we would expect to see margin performance consistent with that. I'm actually pretty pleased that we can get a very, very short-term air pocket and continue to put up 4.2% operating margins. And with that, we've had Japan, we've had the acquisition of the sites in France and Italy, we've had some near-term disruptions from the High Velocity segment. And the company is still turning in pretty good numbers. So I'm actually pretty pleased with it.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Forbes, if I can just start with buyback authorization, that appears to be a change in tone. Historically, the focus has been predominantly on the dividend, as well as may be some M&A. So if you could just talk about the buyback, what that means? And then
componenttext: Forbes, if I can just start with buyback authorization, that appears to be a change in tone. Historically, the focus has been predominantly on the dividend, as well as may be some M&A. So if you could just talk about the buyback, what that means? And then also as it relates to free cash flow generation you expect going forward?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, in terms of the first part of your question, I want to be clear that in terms of the share repurchase, this is not a signal that we're not actively looking or interested in terms of acquisition. Where it makes sense particularly in Diversified Manuf
componenttext: Sure, in terms of the first part of your question, I want to be clear that in terms of the share repurchase, this is not a signal that we're not actively looking or interested in terms of acquisition. Where it makes sense particularly in Diversified Manufacturing Services area. So that's all intact and part of our overall operating model. We saw second sequential significant cash flow from operations this quarter, free cash flows that have been generated year-to-date after capital expenditures in the dividends came in at $45 million, somewhere in the region of $200 million of free cash flow have been generated for the 9 months today. As we move into the fourth fiscal quarter, given you're sequentially consistent revenue stream at the midpoint of our guidance. We'll continue to see significant free cash flow generation in the fourth fiscal quarter. So the management team and the board saw it appropriate to look at a more holistic way capital structure here and saw an opportunity to put forward a modest share repurchase and help minimize some of the dilution in terms of the share count as we move forward here. But as we look in fiscal '12, we continue to see significant cash flow generation and allow us to fund internally our growth organically with some modest investments and acquisitions.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And if I could follow-up, in '10, any update in terms of how the Green Point business is tracking to expectations? And then also, any color on just the customer diversification within that business?
componenttext: And if I could follow-up, in '10, any update in terms of how the Green Point business is tracking to expectations? And then also, any color on just the customer diversification within that business?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: It is tracking expectations, both from a revenue and earnings standpoint and I'm pretty pleased with the level of synergistic value that the materials technology group brings to our other business areas, notably areas like healthcare and Clean Tech. And w
componenttext: It is tracking expectations, both from a revenue and earnings standpoint and I'm pretty pleased with the level of synergistic value that the materials technology group brings to our other business areas, notably areas like healthcare and Clean Tech. And we'll continue to press that advantage. And short-term Craig, I mean it's tough to claim significant customer diversification it in these arbitrary 90-day windows. But I think the path that they're on, they're doing business with some of the best smartphone companies in the world. They are engaged in tablets in the entire ecosystem around Mobility and the Mobility Internet and doing business with the leaders, and that's an indication that the technology they have and the differentiation they can bring those customers. So we'll continue to see customer diversification and the market during today and we'll continue to see synergistic value we add to the other target segments, particularly as we get into fiscal 2012.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Wamsi Mohan of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Wamsi Mohan of Bank of America.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're continuing to post very solid year-over-year growth in DMS. But when you look at the percent of revenue, you've been increasing roughly at the rate of about one percentage point a quarter. So from 34% on 1Q to 36% here in about 4Q. So at this rate,
componenttext: You're continuing to post very solid year-over-year growth in DMS. But when you look at the percent of revenue, you've been increasing roughly at the rate of about one percentage point a quarter. So from 34% on 1Q to 36% here in about 4Q. So at this rate, you'll be somewhat short of your 45% goal for the full year of 2013 weeks unless the pace of those accelerates. So it's your expectation that the rate of change in your max towards DMS will actually accelerate over the next few quarters? And what area within DMS do you think will be the key driver of that acceleration?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I beg to differ with you on that, Wamsi because part of the headwinds in getting Diversified Manufacturing Services through a higher percentage of overall business in fiscal '11 is what to. Enterprise infrastructure will be up 18% for the year. High Veloc
componenttext: I beg to differ with you on that, Wamsi because part of the headwinds in getting Diversified Manufacturing Services through a higher percentage of overall business in fiscal '11 is what to. Enterprise infrastructure will be up 18% for the year. High Velocity will be up 10% for the year and if they moderate to the long-term growth targets of 5% to 10% and we continue to deliver 20% to 30% growth in diversified manufacturing services. We should end up right about where we sat in the analyst meeting in the first week of May, that by 2013, diversified manufacturing services would end up at around 45% of our business. And so I look at it, I think we're on track. We just have a little stronger growth in High Velocity in enterprise infrastructure this year. We'll take that when it comes up and there's some opportunity for us to grow the business. You asked about particular business areas. Very excited about all three. I hate to be such a so nondescript in terms of what areas are strong than others but we have great things going on in healthcare. And if you look at the Healthcare & Instrumentation, there's a very significant resumption in growth in that area in the third fiscal quarter. We are investing significantly in that area, both from an SG&A, product development and new product ramp standpoint. Forbes indicated that a little bit. So in the next few years, we're very excited about that business area. That's a tougher area to grow. It takes more investment, more infrastructure, more focus. The individual program wins tend to be a little bit smaller from a revenue standpoint, and they take a longer time to get into the revenue stream. I think that's consistent with probably the narrative that you heard from some of the other players that have a significant healthcare business. So we're very excited about it. It grew 31%. They're expected to grow 31% based on the midpoint of Q4 guidance in 2011 and continue to be excited about 2012 and 2013. Industrial and healthcare, good growth in 2011 and I expect to get at least consistent growth in 2012, 2013. And then Specialized Services, I think it's been such a huge year of growth in Materials Technology Group. I wouldn't expect to double the size of that group again in 2012, and again in 2013. But I expect it to continue to see growth there and we're looking to create opportunities for additional growth in the Aftermarket Services. We think we have a great solution there. We've grown that business strictly organically and we may turn our attention to ways to accelerate the growth there. So, we expect all 3 business areas to contribute and we feel like we're right on track to have diversified manufacturing services end up at 45% to 50% of our business by the time we get into the 2013 timeframe.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot. I appreciate the color there. As a quick follow-up, when you incorporated within your guidance, is there any impact, a from Japan and b, from the recently acquired sites in fiscal fourth quarter guidance?
componenttext: Thanks a lot. I appreciate the color there. As a quick follow-up, when you incorporated within your guidance, is there any impact, a from Japan and b, from the recently acquired sites in fiscal fourth quarter guidance?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the negative impact of the sites in Western Europe will be consistent with the third quarter. So there will be continued dilution in enterprise infrastructure associated with that area. We may see margins pick up just a tad, but very consiste
componenttext: Yes. I think the negative impact of the sites in Western Europe will be consistent with the third quarter. So there will be continued dilution in enterprise infrastructure associated with that area. We may see margins pick up just a tad, but very consistent with what happened in Q3. And there is a continuing effect from Japan although that has been incorporated into the guidance.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Lou Miscioscia of Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Lou Miscioscia of Collins Stewart.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe going back to the SG&A line and the extra $6 million, in the past, you used to turn that into profit pretty quickly. Maybe just comment about the extra spending there and how quickly you expect to get a return on that?
componenttext: Maybe going back to the SG&A line and the extra $6 million, in the past, you used to turn that into profit pretty quickly. Maybe just comment about the extra spending there and how quickly you expect to get a return on that?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I said in my prepared remarks, from resources associated with ongoing ramps in diversified manufacturing. Mentioned another question resources healthcare. So I would certainly expect that through the first fiscal quarter of '12. So let's get throu
componenttext: Yes, as I said in my prepared remarks, from resources associated with ongoing ramps in diversified manufacturing. Mentioned another question resources healthcare. So I would certainly expect that through the first fiscal quarter of '12. So let's get through the next year of the balance of this quarter and we'd expect to see effectively returns coming from that in the first fiscal quarter, the November quarter of this calendar year. So very, very quickly, a little bit ahead of ourselves here. But well-positioned and good growth coming in that first fiscal quarter.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Switching over to Tim, can you maybe just give us some thoughts what you're seeing out there from an organic demand standpoint? Maybe differentiate a little bit from the new wins that you had? Obviously, always a concern from investors as to how demand's
componenttext: Switching over to Tim, can you maybe just give us some thoughts what you're seeing out there from an organic demand standpoint? Maybe differentiate a little bit from the new wins that you had? Obviously, always a concern from investors as to how demand's going to come and play in and especially I guess over the last month, a lot of gyration going on in Europe and a bit here in the U.S. too with the macro slowing?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, you know what, it's a great question Lou. When I think about the overall macro environment, I mean just generally a note, I apologize if these statements are so general, if they're worthless. GDP growth in our country was 1.9%, I guess, in the first
componenttext: Yes, you know what, it's a great question Lou. When I think about the overall macro environment, I mean just generally a note, I apologize if these statements are so general, if they're worthless. GDP growth in our country was 1.9%, I guess, in the first calendar quarter. If I look at demand patterns, the way customers are behaving today, I don't see any big change. I don't see any big change in Europe, I don't see any big change in North America. Continues to be relatively robust, Latin America continues to be pretty robust. So I'm not see a lot of changes. We absorbed kind of deceleration of GDP growth in the developed world over the course of the first calendar quarter. And I don't know of any significant changes to that kind of tone. And if anything, anecdotally, I'd say that people are becoming a little bit more optimistic about late 2011 and prospects in 2012. I know that doesn't quite square with CNN and particularly Fox but that's kind of the way that I see it in the real world. The healthcare demand is good. Instrumentation demand is okay. Industrial Clean Tech and the other areas seem to be good and diversified manufacturing services. Enterprise infrastructure is a little bit more of a mixed bag for us. We see very good demand in storage and our Telecommunications business seems to be in pretty good shape. And then High Velocity actually, things are okay. And with the exception of the one business area that Forbes mentioned, everything seems to be tracking as planned. So I think we we're in the midst of a slow, somewhat choppy economic recovery that continues to seem sustainable from our vantage point.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just one quick follow-up on what you just said on the high velocity, in the next quarter, do you expect a decent rebound across the board in high velocity? Because you only talked about normal seasonality and expecting some new programs to sort of ramp up
componenttext: Just one quick follow-up on what you just said on the high velocity, in the next quarter, do you expect a decent rebound across the board in high velocity? Because you only talked about normal seasonality and expecting some new programs to sort of ramp up.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it serves fiscal Q4 or fiscal Q1?
componenttext: I think it serves fiscal Q4 or fiscal Q1?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Q1.
componenttext: Well, Q1.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, so you have to take Q4 for what it is. When we look at fiscal Q1, based on the health of the other areas of high velocity, we think it's reasonable for investors to expect that our normal seasonal uptick in high velocity will occur in November quarte
componenttext: Yes, so you have to take Q4 for what it is. When we look at fiscal Q1, based on the health of the other areas of high velocity, we think it's reasonable for investors to expect that our normal seasonal uptick in high velocity will occur in November quarter and that quarter would typically be up 15% to 20% in that business area. So if you excluded the Mobility area from high velocity as an area of concern and uncertainty, the balance of high velocity, we would expect to see normal seasonal patterns in our November quarter.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the DMS margins. Can you just talk about the performance you had in this quarter and would you expect the margins I guess to be a little bit better than the 10 basis points expansion given the revenue growth in the quarter? And then wha
componenttext: Just a question on the DMS margins. Can you just talk about the performance you had in this quarter and would you expect the margins I guess to be a little bit better than the 10 basis points expansion given the revenue growth in the quarter? And then what is to taper the segments to get to the 7% part of margins, which is at the midpoint of the range?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it was up 10 basis points quarter-over-quarter. And I think it's a bit of a justified callout but the SG&A expenses, we talked about in terms of ramping the healthcare program and additional. When we provide you operating margins per segment, that
componenttext: I think it was up 10 basis points quarter-over-quarter. And I think it's a bit of a justified callout but the SG&A expenses, we talked about in terms of ramping the healthcare program and additional. When we provide you operating margins per segment, that's fully allocated. All corporate, all SG&A, all product development resources -- I mean the whole thing. So when we overshoot SG&A by $4 million, $5 million, $6 million and a lot of that is because of the investments and in target markets, that's going to have a near-term impact to operating margins. So again, I look at it, these 90-day period. I wouldn't dwell on that entirely. It is up 10 basis points, it is in the target range of 6% to 8% and we continue to see margin expansion, diversified manufacturing services. We will see more of the pipeline of activity that we expect, particularly for fiscal '12 to come into the revenue stream and to get into the mature levels of production.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sorry, can you hit the 7% op margin? Is it a question of just absorbing the costs out there or is it more you guys take some internal issues there?
componenttext: Sorry, can you hit the 7% op margin? Is it a question of just absorbing the costs out there or is it more you guys take some internal issues there?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let's talk about whether it's 6.2% is an issue. We don't believe it's an issue. So there's no need for us to get to 7% operating margins in diversified manufacturing services. Based on the way things are laid out right now, yes, we overshot SG&A. If
componenttext: Well, let's talk about whether it's 6.2% is an issue. We don't believe it's an issue. So there's no need for us to get to 7% operating margins in diversified manufacturing services. Based on the way things are laid out right now, yes, we overshot SG&A. If we hadn't overshot SG&A and made important investments, new programs, new capabilities, then the margins would've been higher in the short-term and lower in the long-term with lower growth opportunities. So we're investing in the short term and that infrastructure will get absorbed as programs that we're winning move into the revenue stream over the course of fiscal '12.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just from the enterprise side, of the 50 basis points drive I think roughly because of the European side, is there a timeline on when that gets completely absorbed and the headwind gets taken out? Or should we just recalibrate longer marg
componenttext: Got it. And then just from the enterprise side, of the 50 basis points drive I think roughly because of the European side, is there a timeline on when that gets completely absorbed and the headwind gets taken out? Or should we just recalibrate longer margins there?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're going to have to go to work on that. We don't want you to recalibrate your margins expectations long term because the 4% to 4.5% is a good range. But it's going to be, over the next quarter or 2, it's going to be tough for us to move back into the h
componenttext: We're going to have to go to work on that. We don't want you to recalibrate your margins expectations long term because the 4% to 4.5% is a good range. But it's going to be, over the next quarter or 2, it's going to be tough for us to move back into the high end of that range. We're just going to have to move more business in those sites. We have to find business opportunities for them and create some additional revenue. And we're hard at work on that. The business is performing really well.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander of Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander of Raymond James.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sorry if I missed this earlier but what's was driving the bigger than normal guidance range for revenue and EPS? It sounds like demand is generally good across your segments. Is it really more around the uncertainty in the Mobility segment? Is it more tie
componenttext: Sorry if I missed this earlier but what's was driving the bigger than normal guidance range for revenue and EPS? It sounds like demand is generally good across your segments. Is it really more around the uncertainty in the Mobility segment? Is it more tied to Japan, supply chain issues? Or have you seen some companies in near term bookings standard? Then I have a follow-up.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we think you given the fact that we're guiding High Velocity down by 13%, I mean we'd like to think that's as conservative as a reasonable person would make it. But there is additional uncertainty because of that. We think we've done an appropriate jo
componenttext: No, we think you given the fact that we're guiding High Velocity down by 13%, I mean we'd like to think that's as conservative as a reasonable person would make it. But there is additional uncertainty because of that. We think we've done an appropriate job of handicapping the full impact of Japan. I wouldn't call that an uncertainty that gives us a lot of concern. We just think it's a smart time for us to be a little bit more conservative, open up the range a little bit and given the environment and what you read a newspaper on health, the that's appropriate. And if you look at the guidance ranges of other people in our business or even customers on a percentage basis or anything else, this is not a wide range.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Forbes, I think you mentioned earlier a 3% SG&A ratio for FY '12 that you would target. If I back out the loss from Europe in the third quarter results, I think your gross margins would've been I think you said 15 basis points higher. So 7.7%-is
componenttext: Okay. And Forbes, I think you mentioned earlier a 3% SG&A ratio for FY '12 that you would target. If I back out the loss from Europe in the third quarter results, I think your gross margins would've been I think you said 15 basis points higher. So 7.7%-ish. And I know you don't manage the business to gross margin but is there any reason you can sustain that kind of gross margin level for FY '12 on given the mix shift you're seeing in the business? Because obviously if you did, your operating margins would be up in FY '12 versus FY '11.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't see any reason Brian that we can't sustain operating margins in the areas you just discussed. We would expect to see continued overall core operating margin in expansion fiscal '12 over fiscal '11. We're not going to provide guidance today bu
componenttext: Yes, I don't see any reason Brian that we can't sustain operating margins in the areas you just discussed. We would expect to see continued overall core operating margin in expansion fiscal '12 over fiscal '11. We're not going to provide guidance today but certainly, we don't see anything that would prohibit that continued core margin expansion in fiscal '12.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Hannan of Needham and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Hannan of Needham and Company.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: So question around the margins in Italy and France, since we noticed to be a drag and thanks for calling that out, specifically today. What should we be expecting from these regions? I know you gave a little bit of a comment around the next quarter but is
componenttext: So question around the margins in Italy and France, since we noticed to be a drag and thanks for calling that out, specifically today. What should we be expecting from these regions? I know you gave a little bit of a comment around the next quarter but is there a specific plan in place around how we drive this to corporate levels and to what extent we can either think of this linearly or how long we might anticipate this?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you need to at least wait for the next couple of quarters. We have internal plans that are in place. I can't provide you any information at this point on what the progress is. Not because I don't want to. It's just because it's early in the proces
componenttext: I think you need to at least wait for the next couple of quarters. We have internal plans that are in place. I can't provide you any information at this point on what the progress is. Not because I don't want to. It's just because it's early in the process.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just shifting gears, from a very high level, when you look at what you're doing within your DMS business, is there a way, perhaps, Tim if you could elaborate on, what some of your more recent learning points have been as you shifted that st
componenttext: Okay. And then just shifting gears, from a very high level, when you look at what you're doing within your DMS business, is there a way, perhaps, Tim if you could elaborate on, what some of your more recent learning points have been as you shifted that strategy and how would you characterize the adjustments that you've needed to make or perhaps that are requiring a more scrutinizing eye in order to reach the goals that you've set forth over the next year or 2?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have a lot of fun doing it. Of course, you learn a lot as you go along. And I'll answer the question, if I haven't answered the question, you can follow-up before we go to the next person, but we're having a lot of fun with it because we get to doing r
componenttext: We have a lot of fun doing it. Of course, you learn a lot as you go along. And I'll answer the question, if I haven't answered the question, you can follow-up before we go to the next person, but we're having a lot of fun with it because we get to doing really nifty products. We're doing new things with capabilities that we haven't had before, and I think one of the things that we've learned is that, particularly in areas like healthcare and in light services, gosh, takes a different level of infrastructure than the generic EMS industry approach. To really drive the differentiation takes investment, it takes better people and a higher level of expertise and it's common in the industry. And so that's part of the investments that we're making, particularly in healthcare, part of a big CapEx plan we've had over the last 12 to 18 months to build up diversified services. And we're just learning that to talk about differentiation, a lot different than being differentiated and being differentiated takes a lot of hard work to people and really focus investment. And gosh, we're having fun doing that and what as we go and we will continue to focus on that.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve O'Brien of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve O'Brien of JPMorgan.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Looking at the HBS high velocity margins going to the next couple of quarters, we went back last year with customers here sort of firing on all cylinders and the business was maybe 1% operating margin. How things change now that's allowing Jabil to captur
componenttext: Looking at the HBS high velocity margins going to the next couple of quarters, we went back last year with customers here sort of firing on all cylinders and the business was maybe 1% operating margin. How things change now that's allowing Jabil to capture, it might be slightly below the target range but still kind of near 2% margin when you have such volatility in certain customers' demands?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we have been happy with the March performance in high velocity. We've been very happy with the progression in performance in high velocity. And I think that comes down to a lot of the focus we put on lean activities and efficiencies in manufa
componenttext: Yes, I think we have been happy with the March performance in high velocity. We've been very happy with the progression in performance in high velocity. And I think that comes down to a lot of the focus we put on lean activities and efficiencies in manufacturing. So, a lot of effort has gone into that. Last year, where this whole high velocity targeted margins. And as you point out, it's a difficult business to manage. The volatility that we've seen in this area. But with the processes we have in place, our real focus in terms of lean activity and Six Sigma processes, it's bringing it home to the targeted ranges.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have some great customers in that business area. People focused on the marquee customers and focus on the negative side of volatility. But there's a lot of really great positive things in that business area. Our relationship is in great shape and we do
componenttext: We have some great customers in that business area. People focused on the marquee customers and focus on the negative side of volatility. But there's a lot of really great positive things in that business area. Our relationship is in great shape and we do a lot of set top boxes and point-of-sale systems. And we've actually been pretty pleased with those customer relationships and our ability to execute. So as Forbes said, it's really fundamentally about better execution and not wasting a lot of time and effort on suboptimized relationships and areas of the business that represent waste. So it's primarily an execution and improvement in execution is responsible for the improvement of almost 100 basis points of margin in that area year-over-year.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks for that Tim and Forbes there. So if you look again next quarter, is the HBS business relying on a real uptick in the third month in August to get to that down 13% sequential and to get to the kind of near-ish 2% margin?
componenttext: Thanks for that Tim and Forbes there. So if you look again next quarter, is the HBS business relying on a real uptick in the third month in August to get to that down 13% sequential and to get to the kind of near-ish 2% margin?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure we understand that question.
componenttext: I'm not sure we understand that question.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Back-end loaded quarter for HBS in the fiscal fourth quarter, is that your expectation?
componenttext: Back-end loaded quarter for HBS in the fiscal fourth quarter, is that your expectation?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's a fairly sleepy time in high velocity. So things are going along pretty well with the exception of the business areas we've already talked about.
componenttext: It's a fairly sleepy time in high velocity. So things are going along pretty well with the exception of the business areas we've already talked about.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one more quick one if I could, or maybe not so quick. But inventories, they're up a little bit this quarter. Can you comment on Jabil's inventory position and then what you're hearing from customers in terms of inventory and if you get any feedb
componenttext: Okay. And one more quick one if I could, or maybe not so quick. But inventories, they're up a little bit this quarter. Can you comment on Jabil's inventory position and then what you're hearing from customers in terms of inventory and if you get any feedback on some distributors who I know have been pointing to elevated inventory?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jabil grew by $90 million, 2 days out from last quarter, sequentially 3% to 4% sequentially while revenue grew at 8% or 9%. So overall, satisfactory. From managing perspective. We were targeting 8% and we're at 7%. So overall, we're okay with the performa
componenttext: Jabil grew by $90 million, 2 days out from last quarter, sequentially 3% to 4% sequentially while revenue grew at 8% or 9%. So overall, satisfactory. From managing perspective. We were targeting 8% and we're at 7%. So overall, we're okay with the performance. We've taken a couple of days out, is a said. Intensive feedback from customers or suppliers, not hearing anything that is any different than we have done over the last 2 or 3 quarters. I think demand patterns we've seen are pretty steady as we move throughout our quarters. Obviously, you're going to see some seasonality in the Christmas quarter. But otherwise, it does appear to be business as usual something.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I should have mentioned the conversion cycle did improve. But thanks.
componenttext: I should have mentioned the conversion cycle did improve. But thanks.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Jim Suva of Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Jim Suva of Citi.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Congratulations to you and your team there at Jabil. Earlier in the conference call, you'd mentioned that you thought it was a good idea to add a bigger range in your sales and EPS. Traditionally, sales have been about $100 million and EPS $0.04 and now i
componenttext: Congratulations to you and your team there at Jabil. Earlier in the conference call, you'd mentioned that you thought it was a good idea to add a bigger range in your sales and EPS. Traditionally, sales have been about $100 million and EPS $0.04 and now it's $200 million or double that. You thought it might be prudent to do so. Is that because visibility has declined or more because of your Mobility issues that are going on with your customers getting delayed or exactly what's the reason about why now we're doing bigger sales in EPS ranges and should we expect that to be the new norm for Jabil?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just have to take exception with this traditional. Traditionally, we've guided this way. It was a very tight range last quarter and I don't think this is out of character for Jabil for the industry or any lack of visibility or increasing certainty or an
componenttext: I just have to take exception with this traditional. Traditionally, we've guided this way. It was a very tight range last quarter and I don't think this is out of character for Jabil for the industry or any lack of visibility or increasing certainty or anything on that type. We know when you got a business segment down 13% that there's some uncertainty that is contained in a very, very small area. So I feel like maybe we've been providing guidances too tight. And gosh, why do that in a marketplace like this? So no, it has nothing to do with visibility. No, it's got nothing to do with uncertainty. And I would contest the statement that traditionally we've always been at a certain range.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And indeed, past few quarters and I would concur that you've just been a little tighter with the guidance the past few quarters. And historically, going back further than that. Indeed, it is back to what you've kind of given today. So both those sta
componenttext: Okay. And indeed, past few quarters and I would concur that you've just been a little tighter with the guidance the past few quarters. And historically, going back further than that. Indeed, it is back to what you've kind of given today. So both those statements I think were both accurate. When we think about also tracking towards -- you actually opened up the discussion talking about fiscal Q1, about how you expect high velocity more seasonal. One has to ask if one of your customers is missing a little bit of a new population. Should that segment actually be stronger than expected in the November quarter?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Stronger than expected in the November quarter?
componenttext: Stronger than expected in the November quarter?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: The seasonal.
componenttext: The seasonal.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we are just making that this could end up to be a little bit of modeling dilemma. So we're trying to provide some help without providing guidance for fiscal Q1. So we're not providing guidance for fiscal Q1. But if you look at the high velocity ar
componenttext: I think we are just making that this could end up to be a little bit of modeling dilemma. So we're trying to provide some help without providing guidance for fiscal Q1. So we're not providing guidance for fiscal Q1. But if you look at the high velocity area, and you can do what you want with the Mobility area of high velocity. If you'd like to assume that it's going to be better than that in the November quarter because of whatever your reasons are, that's great. I think the main point is that's a high level of uncertainty for us and the balance of the high velocity area is actually in very good shape and we would expect normal seasonal patterns to show up in our November quarter. And we would regard that normal seasonal pattern to be something in the nature of 15% to 20% sequential growth in the high velocity segment. Excluding the uncertainty with the customer you talked about. And when you talk about Enterprise & Infrastructure, not necessarily a seasonal area. But we continue to see some growth there. In Diversified Manufacturing Services, we see excellent growth there. No reason to think that growth will slow down. And keep in mind that there is an area of diversified manufacturing services that will probably see a seasonal uptick in the Materials Technology Group. So in any case, that could actually see some acceleration of growth in that area, depending on how other things go.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great and congratulations again to you and your team there at Jabil.
componenttext: Great and congratulations again to you and your team there at Jabil.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Wittine of Longbow Research.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011

componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. First off, lead times have you seen any hiccups there in the supply chain as it relates to the investments we're making in DMS, CMC machines et cetera?

componenttextpreview: No, we haven't.
componenttext: No, we haven't.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Second, kind of going off of what Tim was just speaking about in high velocity, this point, it seems like appreciate the commentary on how the November quarter could trend or at least directly could trend right now. Looking at next year, it's smartest for
componenttext: Second, kind of going off of what Tim was just speaking about in high velocity, this point, it seems like appreciate the commentary on how the November quarter could trend or at least directly could trend right now. Looking at next year, it's smartest for us is not to get aggressive and model sales, I guess below or at the bottom end of your long-term target growth rate. It seems like it that 5% to 10% you have over the long term, it's going to be very difficult at least for fiscal '12. So am I looking at that this is write, not talking about guidance too specifically for fiscal '12.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's the appropriate way for us to talk about that when we talk about Diversified Manufacturing Services, kind of the midpoint of the long-term target growth range of 20% to 30%, probably the same for enterprise infrastructure, 5% to 10%. A
componenttext: Yes, I think that's the appropriate way for us to talk about that when we talk about Diversified Manufacturing Services, kind of the midpoint of the long-term target growth range of 20% to 30%, probably the same for enterprise infrastructure, 5% to 10%. And sure, it might be high velocity. That might be a little more difficult to be near the high end, modeling the low end of that range is probably more appropriate.

So, we've already made some comments about the November quarter for actually all 3 business areas. Not much of a seasonal impact on enterprise infrastructure and diversified manufacturing services tends to be pretty steady. Again in diversified manufacturing services, in the Materials Technology Group, there is some reason to think that the November quarter will be seasonally stronger because of the business mix there. So Diversified Manufacturing Services should be pretty consistent.
