headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Suzanne, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the First Quarter of Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Beth Walters, you ma
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Suzanne, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the First Quarter of Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Beth Walters, you may begin your conference.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to our first quarter of 2011 earnings call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander.This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, ja
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to our first quarter of 2011 earnings call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander.
This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, jabil.com, in the Investors section. Our first quarter press release and corresponding webcast with slides are also available on our website. In these slides, you will find the financial information that we covered during this conference call. We ask that you follow our presentation with the slides on the website and beginning with Slide 2 of forward-looking statement.
During this conference call, we will be making forward-looking statements including those regarding the anticipated outlook for our business, our currently expected second quarter of fiscal 2012 net revenues and earnings results, our long-term outlook for our company and improvements in our operational efficiencies and financial performance. These statements are based on current expectations, forecast and assumptions involving risks and uncertainties that could cause actual outcomes and results to differ materially. An extensive list of these risks and uncertainties are identified in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2010, on subsequent reports on Form 10-Q and Form 8-K and our other securities filings. Jabil disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
You may have noticed in our last earnings call and in our recently published annual report, we have began to highlight operating results. While they are currently still reporting and publishing core results, it is our intention to move fully to GAAP beginning in fiscal 2013. In addition, we'll also be providing guidance on our long-term year-over-year outlook. This change to our guidance aligns more closely with how we do business, taking strategic long-term decisions. We believe providing guidance in this fashion gives investors the most appropriate view into our business.
Today's call will begin with our first quarter and fiscal year results, some comments and highlights from Forbes Alexander on the results as well as guidance on our second fiscal quarter of 2012. Tim Main will then follow with some macro environment and Jabil-specific comments about our performance, our model and our current outlook. We will then open it up to questions from call attendees.
I'll now turn the call over to Forbes.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Beth. Hello, everyone. I'd ask you to refer to Slide 3. Our net revenue for the first quarter was $4.3 billion, an increase of 6% year-over-year. Net operating income was $170.8 million, up 3.9% of revenue, which compares to $156 million, GAAP
componenttext:
Thank you, Beth. Hello, everyone. I'd ask you to refer to Slide 3. Our net revenue for the first quarter was $4.3 billion, an increase of 6% year-over-year. Net operating income was $170.8 million, up 3.9% of revenue, which compares to $156 million, GAAP operating income on revenues of $4.1 billion or 3.8% for the same period in the prior year.
Core operating income excluding the amortization of intangibles, stock-based compensation increased 7% to $194.6 million, represents 4.5% of revenue. This compares to $181.9 million or 4.5% the same period in the prior year.
The sequential basis, revenue increased 1% for the first quarter while core operating income increased 4%. Core diluted earnings per share were $0.65, an increase of 7% over the prior year. GAAP diluted earnings per share for the first quarter was $0.54, an increase of 10% over the prior year. 
Now I'll ask you to refer to Slide 4 for our segment discussion.  In the first quarter, our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment improved 30% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.8 billion, representing 42% of total company revenue. Core operating income expanded in the quarter to 6.8% of revenue. 
The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment increased 4% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.2 billion, representing 28% of total company revenue and core operating income for the segment was 2% of revenue.
The Enterprise & Infrastructure performance was below expectations as we experienced revenue reductions in the quarter as a result of inventory leveling for specific large customers associated with specific mix and the inbound product transitions. We expect to revenue growth and improve core operating income performance for the balance of the fiscal year.
While our High Velocity segment performed above our expectations for the quarter, segment revenues decreased by 14% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.3 billion, representing 30% of total company revenue in the quarter. 
Core operating income for the segment was 3.8% of revenue. And on a sequential basis, we saw strength across the whole segment and core operating income performance exceeded our expectations, primarily as a result of fixed cost leverage in a seasonally high quarter.  
There's also another interesting to note that we have one 10% customer in each of our segments. I'll ask you to refer to Slide 5, the review of our balance sheet metrics. 
We ended the quarter with cash balances over $862 million. Inventory was approximately $2.4 billion, representing 7% increase, primarily associated with our Enterprise & Infrastructure business that we experienced some weakness late in the quarter. Inventory turns remain at 7. Overall, working capital management has remained well controlled. As a result, cash flows from operations was approximately $115 million in the quarter. 
EBITDA in the quarter was $275 million or 6.4%, an expansion of 30 basis points over the same period a year ago.
With regards to capital allocation, we continue to maintain a balanced approach investing in our business and returning cash to shareholders. Our capital expenditures during the quarter were approximately $95 million as we continue to invest in new infrastructure to support our targeted markets and capabilities. For the second quarter of the fiscal year, we expect CapEx levels with approximately $80 million to $90 million, reflective of capacity and infrastructure to support higher levels of production in the second half of the fiscal year.
During the quarter, we increased our quarterly cash dividend by 14%. Bringing our yearly cash dividend to $0.32 per share and while we did not repurchase any shares during the quarter, we still have $100 million available on our authorization for the fiscal year. 
We are also pleased to announce the completion of the Telmar acquisition on December 1. The purchase price of approximately $130 million. I would like to take this opportunity to welcome Telmar employees to Jabil. Moving forward, Telmar's results will be incorporated in the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment, specifically, within the Specialized Services business. Their capability strengthen the depth and scope of our current Aftermarket Services business. Required revenue is approximately $145 million per year.
Now I'll ask you to turn to Slide 6 and 7 for summary of the quarter's performance. We are pleased with the first quarters results. Core operating margin was 4.5%, the high end of our guidance. And revenues at the lower end of our guidance, reflective of continued operational efficiency, diversification of our revenue stream. 
Returns on invested capital calculate on a GAAP net income basis expanded 2% on a year-over-year basis, 26%, providing winning capital returns in the EMS industry.
And I'll ask you to refer to Slide 9 and 10, while I discuss our second quarter guidance. We expect revenue in the second quarter on a year-over-year basis to increase approximately 4%, a range of $4 billion to $4.2 billion. On a sequential basis, overall revenue and operating guidance are consistent with the levels of seasonality we've experienced in fiscal 2011. 
Core operating income is estimated to be in the range of $160 million to $185 million. And core operating margin in the range of 4% to 4.4%. Our core earnings per share will be in the range of $0.52 to $0.62 per diluted share based upon diluted share count of 213 million shares. Based upon the current estimates of production, tax rate on core operating income is expected to be 18% for the quarter and the year.
Turning to our segments. The year-on-year performance for Diversified Manufacturing Services segment is expected to increase 25%; Enterprise & Infrastructure segment is expected to be consistent on a year-over-year basis. Finally, our High Velocity segment is expected to decrease 14% in Year-over-year basis.
And now I would like to hand over the call to Tim Main.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Forbes. For the first fiscal quarter of 2012 is an interesting quarter, very solid results if a little more uneven than we would typically like. Enterprise & Infrastructure was disappointing in total but that underperformance was isolated and w
componenttext:
Thank you, Forbes. For the first fiscal quarter of 2012 is an interesting quarter, very solid results if a little more uneven than we would typically like. Enterprise & Infrastructure was disappointing in total but that underperformance was isolated and we feel confident about Enterprise & Infrastructure going forward. 
We have very good customer relationship in this segment with stable to expanding share of wallet in all major business relationships. We do expect margins to continue expansion as revenue growth as we experienced revenue growth over the balance of the year, along with the benefits of cost reductions already underway to certain sites in Western Europe.
Very strong results and over performance from our Diversified Manufacturing Services group, outstanding margin performance, as well as sequential and year-over-year revenue growth. 
Many of you might be interested in this specific High Velocity customer, which I want to forewarn you, we will not be able to answer any questions about specific customer relationships. However, recognizing the state of uncertainty generally and as a result of some of the more uneven results in fiscal Q2, we thought it would be helpful to help you understand and characterize the balance of our fiscal year. We have prepared some material to help you along with how we see the balance of the fiscal year for our company.
If you could please turn to Slide 12. Using our fiscal first quarter results and the midpoint of our fiscal second quarter guidance, revenue for the first half of fiscal '12 should be approximately $8.4 billion. In the second half of the year, we expect that Diversified Manufacturing group to continue leading growth. We have the organic growth contribution from Aftermarket Services, which is typically at least 12% to 15% per year, combined with the benefit of the Telmar acquisition. We also continue to expect results in Materials Technology Group and the Industrial & Clean Tech and the Healthcare & Instrumentation business areas to continue expansion over the course of the year. 
Given our market share and relatively stable demand trends in the Enterprise & Infrastructure group, and I want to highlight that, we see a relatively stable demand trends in Enterprise & Infrastructure. And we see growth in the second half, exceeding the first half, which we think is reasonable.
We're being conservative about revenue performance and High Velocity in the second of the year. This chart would indicate we are expecting a contraction of approximately $110 million in the second half of the year. However, the quality of that revenue in High Velocity in the margins would continue to be above the high end of our long-term targeted margin range. 
In essence, as a result in the fiscal '12 of approximately $9 billion in the second half and the  total year revenue of about $17.4 billion. We're not trying to handicap anything more or less into this picture, just providing a viewpoint as to where we think we are today and as to how the balance of the year might unfold.
Please turn to Slide 13. Should the year unfold at about this level, I would regard this as a solid year with a good trended business mix towards a Diversified Manufacturing Services business area. Margin and profit expansion can take place on much more moderate revenue growth that which I regard as a very good thing. Please turn to Slide 14.
Diversified Manufacturing Services Group growth is underpinned by a very substantial market opportunity for the company, approximately a $500 billion addressable market with very low levels of penetration. You can find this chart highlighted on our annual report, the fiscal '12 annual report, and it actually goes into additional detail of market subsegment in each of these business areas. Jabil has a leading or at least a beachhead position at all of these areas, and we look to significant growth in these areas over the next 3, 4, 5 years.
Turning to Slide 15, please. So in summary, we regard our first fiscal quarter and the fiscal year to be solid performance in an uncertain environment. We expect moderate revenue growth in fiscal '12. That's a little bit lower than we just experienced historically. But good solid revenue growth underpinned by a strong improvement in portfolio mix towards Diversified Manufacturing Services.
We are continuing our focus on Lean Manufacturing and operating efficiency and all of these elements combined, will help us keep is on track towards a third consecutive record year for the company in terms of revenue and common EPS. Long-term business objectives remain on track. And we look forward to fiscal '12 the fiscal '13 and beyond.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: First question for you, I think last quarter you talk about the business having to sort of outgrow despite the weak macro economic environment. We've now seen year-over-year growth decelerate from a 32% to 4%. Just wondering how you should sort of explain
componenttext: First question for you, I think last quarter you talk about the business having to sort of outgrow despite the weak macro economic environment. We've now seen year-over-year growth decelerate from a 32% to 4%. Just wondering how you should sort of explain that it is your expectation that sort of mid-single-digit is now more of a reasonable growth target for fiscal '12?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, 7% to 8% growth is significantly above macro economic growth. And in fact, I think, we would be in a leading position in terms of S&P 500 companies. And I think that's based on what we see today. So long-term growth objectives remain on track, 20% t
componenttext: Well, 7% to 8% growth is significantly above macro economic growth. And in fact, I think, we would be in a leading position in terms of S&P 500 companies. And I think that's based on what we see today. So long-term growth objectives remain on track, 20% to 30% in Diversified Manufacturing Services and 5% to 10% in the other business years. If you look back in fiscal '12 over growth in fiscal '11 in '12, will certainly be if not in the range above the range of growth for those business areas. So I'm having a hard time getting to your interpretation of where we are. And actually, this growth is in terms of top line growth, it might be a little bit below were analyst had as in the conference call in September. But given the portfolio mix towards Diversified Manufacturing Services, the income and EPS associated with this revenue stream is roughly equivalent. So I would regard this as a nice straight out of lower margin revenue for a better earnings profile and more sustainability. So I think I'd take fiscal '12 particularly in this environment.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just as a quick follow-up perhaps Three Forks, can you help us understand that we should expect in terms of operating margin expectations for HVS and E&I. I think HVS certainly is surprised on the upside and E&I on the downside. Just for the Febr
componenttext: And then just as a quick follow-up perhaps Three Forks, can you help us understand that we should expect in terms of operating margin expectations for HVS and E&I. I think HVS certainly is surprised on the upside and E&I on the downside. Just for the February quarter, how should we be thinking about the movements for these 2 segments?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'll give you some color in general term about specific guidance around each of these segments. But taking Enterprise & Infrastructure, which underperformed in the first quarter that's really now about our revenue growth. And as we have said in ou
componenttext: Yes, so I'll give you some color in general term about specific guidance around each of these segments. But taking Enterprise & Infrastructure, which underperformed in the first quarter that's really now about our revenue growth. And as we have said in our prepared remarks, essentially, the guidance we provide will go through the balance of the second fiscal quarter and the balance of the year. So we should see some pretty reasonable margin progression. I'll remind you that last quarter, we discussed the closure of our sites in Northern Italy. So that's underway. We do anticipate that would occur will be some benefit in the February quarter. All below margin accretion and then we'll see the full benefit of those closures in the third or fourth quarter. But principally, we add back the revenue, we see in the growth and we start to see the margins progress from 2.5%. And I would expect us to be very close to the low end of our operating targets as we get to the first fiscal quarter here. I remind everyone that the long-term targets in the range of 4% to 4.5%. Terms of the High Velocity arena, you see, extremely pleased with the performance in the first fiscal quarter. And the way we think about that is that we did have some high utilization of some assets in the seasonally high first quarter. So I would expect some decline in those margins as we move forward to the balance of the year. Sequentially, we do see revenues coming down as a result of this November high season. So the way to think about that is probably certainly above the high end of our targeted range, 2.5%, somewhere around probably approaching to 3% for the balance of the year.

componenttext: Yes, the revenue underperformance from an Enterprise infrastructure in Q1 was driven by really characterized as about $106 million in $170 million revenue miss about 1/2 was associated with excess inventory, buffer inventory to cover inbound transition of programs from a large customer. And they set up inventory that was larger than needed to support that product transition and we are working on all those buffers now with that customer. And then there was a couple of other customers that are just going through general inventory correction, which we think will rectify very quickly. So I think it's really important to say that underlying demand is relatively stable. We just happen to get hit but with the 2, 3 isolated circumstances, of inbound transition issues and there's a couple of inventory corrections.

componenttext: Got it. That's actually very helpful. So I'm not actually surprised how you have $100 million plus of cash this quarter. Should we expect cash flow to continue to improve throughout fiscal '12 as it has historically tend to do?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's sure and you're absolutely right. Outstanding job in overall working management this quarter. So as we move forward for the balance of the year, I would expect continued strong cash flow from operations performance. Just definitely to produce so
componenttext: Yes, it's sure and you're absolutely right. Outstanding job in overall working management this quarter. So as we move forward for the balance of the year, I would expect continued strong cash flow from operations performance. Just definitely to produce somewhere in the region of $175 million to $200 million plus a quarter as we look out to the balance of the year. So that given with some of the CapEx and the acquisition of Telmar that both on the 1st of November that I think will return somewhere between $210 million of free cash flow in the fiscal year. So again, another very strong year from working capital and cash flow perspective.

componenttext: Yes, Brian, this is Forbes. The sequential guidance is about 3% as we move forward. So that's actually above what we typically see in this February quarter. As we move and I articulated in answer to previous question, there was an market relatively stable from our perspective and the customer relationships other than that. The inbound inventory correction that we saw. But we are seeing growth, we have seen that occur in the last couple of weeks you're in December so we're starting to see growth and we would expect continued growth from the back of the fiscal year also.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then just on the margin on the United Corp., the 60% decline in profitability year-over-year, can you break that out how much of that was due to the one-time restructuring actions versus the operating losses, your European facilities versus mayb
componenttext: Okay, and then just on the margin on the United Corp., the 60% decline in profitability year-over-year, can you break that out how much of that was due to the one-time restructuring actions versus the operating losses, your European facilities versus maybe some of the lower-than-expected volumes that you talked about?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the lower-than-expected volumes, typically what we see in that instance above the 10% deleverage in our revenue. So that's what $16 million of an impact of there but it was late in the quarter. In terms of the year-over-year basis, in our
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the lower-than-expected volumes, typically what we see in that instance above the 10% deleverage in our revenue. So that's what $16 million of an impact of there but it was late in the quarter. In terms of the year-over-year basis, in our first fiscal quarter of last year, as you are aware, we didn't have sites in France and Italy, which are predominantly Enterprise & Infrastructure-focused sites. So this quarter, there was an impact there's that's somewhere between 50 and 70 basis points on that margin. So add those back, we start to be being something 3 points -- approaching 3.5 points, I think my math goes on that. And as I said, earlier, we have started this restructuring process. We do expect the sites in our locations by the end of February, our current target. And we should then see continued pickup in Q3 and then Q4 again as we see revenues continue to ramp towards the low end of our targeted range of 4 to 4.5 points.

componenttext: Yes, just trying basically end demand broadly?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, end demand is actually pretty decent and stable. I mean actually if you go back and look at previous years, Q1 is typically not a very good quarter for us. We had decline in sequential growth in '10 and a decline in sequential growth in '11 and a lit
componenttext: Yes, end demand is actually pretty decent and stable. I mean actually if you go back and look at previous years, Q1 is typically not a very good quarter for us. We had decline in sequential growth in '10 and a decline in sequential growth in '11 and a little bit more of a sequential decline this quarter, but Q2 growth rebound. So underlying demand trends are okay. And that's why we're pointing to a few isolated customer relationships. We don't want to give investors the wrong message because it always seems the flowback to specific customers was can be embarrassing. And, frankly, not true. Computing of the storage market was actually a bright spot. And we've seen very stable demand and we're growing share of wallet in the Storage business area. The Telecommunications area, particularly wireless infrastructure demand is good but we're seeing some inventory leveling and some technology changes that elongate some of the product transitions to Jabil. And then the other elements of Enterprise & Infrastructure. Nothing to write home about in terms of great growth but decent stability and I think most of the marketplace has been sensitized to expect lower levels of annual year-over-year growth in the data communications area in particular. So I think it's that thing remarkable, certainly disappointed in the first fiscal quarter performance relative to our expectation. But relative to previous years performance in fiscal Q1, not a great deal worse than in fiscal '11 and fiscal '10. And actually we'd look to the balance of the year, very high confidence levels of that our revenue growth will resume growth in Q2 and continue throughout the year.

componenttext: I think demand there is really robust given the transition from vertically integrated factories to the virtual manufacturing model when you talk about industrial and healthcare companies, renewable Energy is still good. There are some elements Renewable Energy that could be a bit choppy at this point but certainly is a robust long-term growth area. The Materials Technology Group has very robust demand. And although we do see some seasonality in that business in Q2, given the seasonal sellthrough of the smartphone products that manufacturers technology group builds for. And then the Aftermarket Services area, amongst the Telmar acquisition, solid year-over-year again growth on a steady basis. So DMS, Diversified Manufacturing Services, we expect to continue to see very robust demand services we provide.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ron Mohan.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, you highlighted $600 million incremental revenue on the second half versus first half. And I know it's about the same as what you did last fiscal year if you exclude the Telmar acquisition. So maybe if you can share what you're seeing in the pipeline
componenttext: Tim, you highlighted $600 million incremental revenue on the second half versus first half. And I know it's about the same as what you did last fiscal year if you exclude the Telmar acquisition. So maybe if you can share what you're seeing in the pipeline what's giving you the confidence [indiscernible] that the longer term arguably to uncertainty, it seems much higher in the near term?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] It certainly is increasing. [indiscernible] I think that you often hear out of the faster rate, but I think the overall economic environment isn't getting a lot worse or a lot better, not changing rapidly. They seem to be a little bit bett
componenttext: [indiscernible] It certainly is increasing. [indiscernible] I think that you often hear out of the faster rate, but I think the overall economic environment isn't getting a lot worse or a lot better, not changing rapidly. They seem to be a little bit better in United States, a little bit slower in Europe. Asia continues to be stable. So I think that the economic environment is relatively benign, if you will, in terms of influence. $600 million of incremental revenue growth and as you point out is pretty similar to what we have last year. We see, if you look at the Enterprise & Infrastructure portion of that, we essentially get back $166 million that wasn't there in fiscal Q1 because that's a share of wallet issue and a sellthrough rate issue. So once that inventory is consumed and the 3 product transitions are completed, you get that basically that same runrate back into the revenue stream. And then there is some additional customer programs we expect to ramp in the production over the course of Q3 and Q4. So we feel good about it in Enterprise & Infrastructure, actually, a very good line of sight to that as well. And in the Diversified Manufacturing Services, gosh with 30% year-over-year in Q1. Materials technology Aftermarket Services and industrial all have a very good growth prospects for the balance of the year. We're actually, we have seen growth here in areas like Defense & Aerospace, so we feel good about line of sight to growth in those areas as well. And I think one of the reasons we want to make sure that investors are in touch with what we think is a realistic perspective on the High Velocity business segment and actually seeing that contract in the second half of the year. And that attenuates the revenue growth for the year, again the margin profile and earnings power of the company is unaffected by that actually improved by that change out of high velocity revenue for Enterprise infrastructure and Diversified Manufacturing Services. So actually a pretty good trade out in our calculus of how the year should unfold. I think what you got to do to put faith in this is you've got to believe that macroeconomic conditions continue at about the same rate. And again, I made the comment during my prepared remarks that we're not trying to handicap anything more or less into this guidance, simply what we see today based on sellthrough rates and the current economic environment. If you someone who thinks the environment is going to get a lot worse, then this is probably something you want to have faith in. If you believe the economic environment will probably continue to be relatively tepid or lackluster, I think this is something you can put a lot of faith in. I think the company has put up spectacular results in the face of significant macro economic headwinds. And I don't think those headwinds are any worse today than they have been of fiscal '11 or previously. So we wanted to help people understand how we see the balance of the year by giving all the moving parts in all of the collateral information that people have been getting over the last 3 or 4 months and worrying about frankly. So we're looking for what we think is a pretty solid year maybe a little bit lower revenue growth, but earnings that will compare very favorably with fiscal '11.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011

componenttext: Thanks, that's very helpful. And then quick clarification on the High Velocity, $110 million decline in the second half. Is that just an expectation are just broad-based, more or fairly concentrated sort of across a couple of across customers?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's fairly concentrated in specific product categories. I think it's kind of interesting, if you look at High Velocity year-over-year in fiscal Q1, we've really reduced our exposure to the mobility EMS handset business and the TV set displays business. T
componenttext: It's fairly concentrated in specific product categories. I think it's kind of interesting, if you look at High Velocity year-over-year in fiscal Q1, we've really reduced our exposure to the mobility EMS handset business and the TV set displays business. The rest, if you exclude the displays and the handset business, the rest of High Velocity is actually very stable to up year-over-year. And businesses alike Automotive have been robust. Our printing business is strong with good year-over-year growth. So point-of-sale systems is good, and so we're actually excluding the areas of the business where we've kind of intentionally pushed away from or deemphasized. High Velocity is actually in pretty good shape. So that revenue degradation as specific to certain product areas.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Harrison.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on HVS with margins running better than kind of the long-term target here and you deemphasizing some of the EMS handset time business in the panels I guess what would push it back to where that 2.5% target as you get into the fiscal '13?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on HVS with margins running better than kind of the long-term target here and you deemphasizing some of the EMS handset time business in the panels I guess what would push it back to where that 2.5% target as you get into the fiscal '13? Is it solely mix or something us that we should be looking for or on the other hand kind of  running in 3% going forward?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's reasonable to think that High Velocity given what we see today can run for the year kind of above at about 3% or a little bit better so to be above our long-term of our targeted range. I think opportunistically, it's an opportunistic bu
componenttext: Well, I think it's reasonable to think that High Velocity given what we see today can run for the year kind of above at about 3% or a little bit better so to be above our long-term of our targeted range. I think opportunistically, it's an opportunistic business area by nature. If we find opportunities to expand the business, we'd be looking for areas where there's higher value opportunities for the company. I think we'll take a look at our long-term targets for High Velocity closer to the end of the year when we kind of refresh for fiscal year '13. But I think Forbes and I will be comfortable with the expectation that High Velocity operating margins for the year can start with a 3, probably somewhere in the low 3s. And we expect to see and I think we mentioned this in our prepared remarks or Q&A, but we do see Enterprise & Infrastructure margins improved over the course of the year by about 50 basis points so if you kind of do that and you've got consistent margins in the Diversified Manufacturing Services area, which we think is a reasonable expectation, that's why we think the earnings power of the company is in pretty good shape for the year.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011

componenttext: Okay, very helpful. And this is a brief follow-up I guess inventory expectations for the February quarter, would you expect inventory dollars to decline? And then on the buyback I guess what are you looking at in terms of the stock price anything like that just to maybe complete the $100 million authorization out there?

componenttext: Let me have the last portion on the price. As we noted in the prepared remarks, we do have a off evaluation of $100 million available to us. And the intent there is that we use that during the fiscal year. So you should start to see us put that in action as we move through the coming quarters here. But we wouldn't expect us to use that in any one particular quarter, but a measured approach as we move through the balance of the fiscal year. In terms of inventory, yes, we see trends declining in of inventory. And certainly expect to gain back was it $160 million or so of potential increase in the quarter to bring that back down to Q4 levels or overall.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a question on DMS. Tim, you talked about, you give some guidance for growth for the next quarter and then you also talked about some seasonality in the material side, particularly with Green Point and the smartphone exposure there. But aside from Gre
componenttext: Just a question on DMS. Tim, you talked about, you give some guidance for growth for the next quarter and then you also talked about some seasonality in the material side, particularly with Green Point and the smartphone exposure there. But aside from Green Point and the smartphone exposure, is there much seasonality on to that business because over the last few quarters, you have been growing sequentially ever quarter and obviously, with the good pipeline but how do you see that playing out from seasonality standpoint aside from some of the specialized manufacturing business?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, experience would say that it's typically not a great quarter for growth anyways even though we're not relying on end market growth and Diversified Manufacturing Services really planning on market penetration of our industry, it still tends to be a r
componenttext: Well, experience would say that it's typically not a great quarter for growth anyways even though we're not relying on end market growth and Diversified Manufacturing Services really planning on market penetration of our industry, it still tends to be a relatively small period. That said, so no, there's not much seasonality although it tends to be, it's not intuitive but it's seasonal, but it tends to be relatively slow period anyways. And just based on our empirical evidence of behaviors. But the pipeline of growth and those businesses, industrial, the Clean Tech area, the healthcare area, very, very strong performance. We do have some exposure in the Instrumentation part of Healthcare Instrumentation, there is some semiconductor capital equipment content that is very weak right now and that runs through the system. I think we'll see good year-over-year growth as the balance of the year unfolds.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011

componenttext: Okay, great. And then looking at Thailand, I know you have a little bit of exposure in manufacturing on the industrial side there and then obviously, it's a big source of supply and components, particularly on the hard drive side. Have you seen any impact at all, negative or positive, from Thailand both from a customer standpoint and the supply standpoint?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Very, very little. There are some impact but very little impact to Q1. I think we'll probably see some impact in Q2. We've got some actual -- a number of things going on in Q2 that are handicapped into the guidance. So I don't want to belabor the point, b
componenttext: Very, very little. There are some impact but very little impact to Q1. I think we'll probably see some impact in Q2. We've got some actual -- a number of things going on in Q2 that are handicapped into the guidance. So I don't want to belabor the point, but this Chinese New Year, there's fewer working days in Q2. There will be some impact in our High Velocity business area related to Set-top boxes we anticipate due to the Thailand flooding. And our guys are working feverishly to offset that impact. But expectations now that will be some impact but relatively modest.

componenttext: Okay. Looking of the CapEx for this quarter, I think that the expectation if I wrote about right was that the CapEx might be a little bit lower in fiscal '12 versus '11, but kind of we're at parity sort of one quarter end. And clearly, sounds like there is some ramping expected for the second half of the year, so I mean I just want to check if you're revising that CapEx expectation. And secondly, on free cash flow, with respect to sort of the range of outcomes, would you expect it to be sort of lower if the year strengthens on working capital and higher if kind of  remains the same or not?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Steve, in terms of the CapEx, we've guided into the first quarter right about $100 million. We came in just on $95 million actually for our first quarter. So our overall expectations for the year, if we add in our second fiscal quarter, the point of guida
componenttext: Steve, in terms of the CapEx, we've guided into the first quarter right about $100 million. We came in just on $95 million actually for our first quarter. So our overall expectations for the year, if we add in our second fiscal quarter, the point of guidance is $85 million, it's somewhere between $350 million and $400 million in terms of capital expenditures for the year is where our thoughts are currently. So last year, we spend on a net basis I think $136 million something of that nature, so a little bit shy of that. Obviously, we have this Telmar acquisition of $130 million so investors at that point in terms of modeling cash flows. In terms of the overall cash flows, I think the question for performance in terms of cash flow depending on revenue growth. Currently, with the back half of the year that we articulated in the prepared remarks today, the working capital management has really been outstanding in my opinion outstanding over the last multiple of quarters actually that's 5 or 6 quarters. And I didn't want to see anything that will change that level of performance as I look through the balance of the fiscal year. So what that does based on the view we have of the balance of our fiscal year, certainly, provides us an opportunity of somewhere in that $175 million, $200 million plus a quarter of operating cash flow. CapEx levels and expenses we talked about and you're producing $250 million of free cash flow for the year. If revenue should grow faster than in our back half of the fiscal year, there will be some degradation to those cash flows, purely based upon the amendment the working capital that we need. The way we specifically think about that is somewhere in the region of $0.05 to $0.10 of the working capital need for that incremental dollar and revenue. Should we see softness and clearly, cash flows would outperform these levels I have just discussed.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Craig, I think it's a really fair question. We've read about a number of investors ask us to articulate a policy around dividends and share repurchases, I mean and some relationship to free cash flow operating profit, some metric that investors can use to
componenttext: Craig, I think it's a really fair question. We've read about a number of investors ask us to articulate a policy around dividends and share repurchases, I mean and some relationship to free cash flow operating profit, some metric that investors can use to hold management accountable for return of value to shareholders. We're not prepared to articulate that today, but we are working on that type of policy. And we think by the time we start talking about fiscal '13, Forbes and I will have a position on how we look at dividends long term and share repurchases and the role they play and how we deploy free cash flow. I think having said that, we're not a company that thinks that the management team should, all excess cash. We think our first priority is to invest the cash in the business. We had a slide that shows our 26% GAAP income return on invested capital. Our cost of capital is under 9%. So this is a very high return investment of the dollars. And we'll look to have out be consistent in terms of investing in the business. But beyond that, we will look to dividend expansion and share repurchases and other ways of returning capital.

componenttext: When you look at the EPS leverage potential for Jabil, it's been a long-time since we've kind of had a steady environment, a lot of cycles, down cycles in the past 3 years. componenttext: Just keep in mind when you compare fiscal Q1 '12 to fiscal Q1 '11, fiscal Q1 '11 does not include the operations in France and Italy that were acquired, reacquired and that diluted income, $5 million to $10 million, and so there was some leverage. headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's a good question. I'm not sure I know how to convert the comment into -- I'm not sure high to quantitatively convert the comment, but a little bit of tailwind would be exponentially good for the business, particularly when you look at
componenttext: Well, I think that's a good question. I'm not sure I know how to convert the comment into -- I'm not sure high to quantitatively convert the comment, but a little bit of tailwind would be exponentially good for the business, particularly when you look at infrastructure spend where we do have a pretty decent market share with customers and the customers in the Enterprise & Infrastructure group. I guess some tailwind that will be exponentially better for the business. I think just having a stable to slightly positively biased environment would put Healthcare & Industrial types of customers that are presently vertically integrated in the cost and be a little bit more aggressive and comfortable with an outsourced model. The level of uncertainty of not knowing which way things are going to go just naturally causes conservative people to pull their horns in. And in an outstanding environment that's necessarily accelerate the outsourcing. But if there was a positive advise, which felt like the ground firm underneath their feet, we might see an acceleration of outsourcing from presently vertically integrated companies.

componenttext: Tim, I wanted to ask you about Diversified Manufacturing Services. That segment seems to be at least this quarter driven primarily by the Specialized Services segment and if we look on a quarter-over-quarter basis, Industrial and Healthcare segments seem to be a bit weaker. Can you give us some outlook in terms of what you are seeing in those segments and what are your expectations for the balance of the year? headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011

componenttext: I think Specialized Services given the acquisition of Telmar and the outstanding growth of Materials Technology Group that they will continue to lead the pack in terms of a Diversified Manufacturing Services. But we do see more significant growth from the Healthcare & Instrumentation and the Industrial & Clean Tech groups in the second half of the year. And now unfortunately, we've not been able to turn growth in those areas into the linear growth ramps. They tend to be relatively stairstep and come in some chunks with stairstep and then moderate growth sequentially. And that's why we're really converting or thinking to looking at things in a year-over-year basis because it does a better job of characterizing the actual growth rate in those areas. The other thing I say, Sheree, is just looking at the present core and the present environment the semi-cap equipment area of Industrial & Clean Tech and Healthcare & Instrumentation group, that is weak and diluting the results in that area. We expect that to kind of either stay where it is or maybe even modestly improve in fiscal '12, but not looking for that has the impact of diluting the sequential growth on the near term.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Susan, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the First Quarter of Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Beth Walters, you may begin your
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Susan, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the First Quarter of Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Beth Walters, you may begin your conference.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to our first quarter of 2012 earnings call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander.This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, ja
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to our first quarter of 2012 earnings call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander.
This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, jabil.com, in the Investors section. Our first quarter press release and corresponding webcast with slides are also available on our website. In these slides, you will find the financial information that we covered during this conference call. We ask that you follow our presentation with the slides on the website beginning with Slide 2 of forward-looking statement.
During this conference call, we will be making forward-looking statements, including those regarding the anticipated outlook for our business, our currently expected second quarter of fiscal 2012 net revenue and earnings results, our long-term outlook for our company and improvements in our operational efficiencies and financial performance. These statements are based on current expectations, forecasts and assumptions involving risks and uncertainties that could cause actual outcomes and results to differ materially. An extensive list of these risks and uncertainties are identified in our annual report on Form 10-K for fiscal year ended August 31, 2011, on subsequent reports on Form 10-Q and Form 8-K and our other securities filings. Jabil disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
You may have noticed in our last earnings call and in our recently published annual report we have begun to highlight GAAP operating results. While we are currently still reporting and publishing core results, it is our intention to move fully to GAAP beginning in fiscal 2013. In addition, we'll also be providing guidance on our long-term year-over-year outlook. This change to our guidance aligns more closely with how we've run the business, taking strategic long-term decisions. We believe providing guidance in this fashion gives investors the most appropriate view into our business.
Today's call will begin with our first quarter results highlights and comments from Forbes Alexander on the results as well as guidance on our second fiscal quarter of 2012. Tim Main will follow with some macroenvironment and Jabil-specific comments about our performance, our model and our current outlook. We will then open it up to questions from our call attendees.
I'll now turn the call over to Forbes.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Beth. Hello, everyone. I'll ask you to refer to Slide 3. Our net revenue for the first quarter was $4.3 billion, an increase of 6% year-over-year. GAAP operating income was $170.8 million, or 3.9% of revenue, which compares to $156 million GAAP
componenttext:
Thank you, Beth. Hello, everyone. I'll ask you to refer to Slide 3. Our net revenue for the first quarter was $4.3 billion, an increase of 6% year-over-year. GAAP operating income was $170.8 million, or 3.9% of revenue, which compares to $156 million GAAP operating income on revenues of $4.1 billion or 3.8% in the same period in the prior year.
Core operating income, excluding the amortization of intangibles and stock-based compensation increased 7% to $194.6 million. It represents 4.5% of revenue. This compares to $181.9 million or 4.5% in the same period in the prior year.
On a sequential basis, revenue increased 1% in the first quarter while core operating income increased 4%. Core diluted earnings per share were $0.65, an increase of 7% over the prior year. GAAP diluted earnings per share for first quarter was $0.54, an increase of 10% over the prior year. 
Now I ask you to refer to Slide 4 for our segment discussion.  In the first quarter, our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment grew 30% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.8 billion, representing 42% of total company revenue. Core operating income expanded in the quarter to 6.8% of revenue. 
The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment increased 4% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.2 billion, representing 28% of total company revenue, and core operating income for the segment was 2% of revenue.
Enterprise & Infrastructure performance was below expectations as we experienced revenue reductions late in the quarter as a result of inventory leveling with specific large customers associated with specific mix and inbound product transitions. We expect a return to revenue growth and improved core operating income performance the balance of the fiscal year.
While our High Velocity segment performed above our expectations for the quarter, segment revenues decreased by 14% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.3 billion, representing 30% of total company revenue in the quarter. Core operating income for the segment was 3.8% of revenue. Now on a sequential basis, we saw strength across the whole segment, and core operating income performance exceeded our expectations primarily as a result of fixed-cost leverage in a seasonally high quarter.  
It's also now interesting to note that we have one 10% customer in each of our segments. I'll ask you to refer to Slide 5, a review of our balance sheet metrics. 
We ended the quarter with cash balances of $862 million. Inventory was approximately $2.4 billion, representing a 7% increase primarily associated with our Enterprise & Infrastructure business where we experienced some weakness late in the quarter. Inventory turns remained at 7. Overall working capital management remained well controlled. As a result, cash flows from operations was approximately $115 million in the quarter. EBITDA in the quarter was $275 million, or 6.4%, an expansion of 30 basis points over the same period a year ago.
With regard to capital allocation, we continue to maintain a balanced approach, investing in our business and returning cash to shareholders. Our capital expenditures during the quarter were approximately $95 million as we continued to invest in new infrastructure to support our targeted markets and capabilities. In the second quarter of the fiscal year, we expect CapEx levels of approximately $80 million to $90 million, reflective of capacity and infrastructure to support higher levels of production in the second half of the fiscal year.
During the quarter, we increased our quarterly cash dividend by 14%, bringing our yearly cash dividend to $0.32 per share. And while we did not repurchase any shares during the quarter, we still have $100 million available on our authorization for the fiscal year. 
We're also pleased to announce the completion of the Telmar acquisition on December 1 with a purchase price of approximately $130 million. I would like to take this opportunity to welcome Telmar employees to Jabil. Moving forward, Telmar's results will be incorporated in our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment, specifically within the specialized services business. Their capabilities strengthen the depth and scope of our current Aftermarket Services business. Required revenue is approximately $145 million per year.
Now I ask you to turn to Slide 6 and 7 for summary of the quarter's performance. We are pleased with the first quarter's results. Core operating margin was 4.5%, the high end of our guidance. And revenue is at the lower end of our guidance, reflective of continued operational efficiency, diversification of our revenue stream. 
Returns on invested capital, calculated on a GAAP net income basis, expanded 2% on a year-over-year basis, 26%, providing leading [ph] capital returns in the EMS industry.
And I'll ask you to refer to Slide 9 and 10 while I discuss our second quarter guidance. We expect revenue in the second quarter on a year-over-year basis to increase approximately 4%, a range of $4 billion to $4.2 billion. On a sequential basis, overall revenue and operating guidance are consistent with the levels of seasonality we experienced in fiscal 2011. 
Core operating income is estimated to be in the range of $160 million to $185 million, and core operating margin in the range of 4% to 4.4%. Our core earnings per share will be in the range of $0.52 to $0.62 per diluted share based upon diluted share count of 213 million shares. Based upon the current estimates of production, tax rate on core operating income is expected to be 18% for the quarter and the year.
Turning to our segments. The year-on-year performance for Diversified Manufacturing Services segment is expected to increase 25%. Enterprise & Infrastructure segment is expected to be consistent on a year-over-year basis. Finally, our High Velocity segment is expected to decrease 14% on a year-over-year basis.
And now I'd like to hand over the call to Tim Main.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Forbes. Well, the first fiscal quarter of 2012 is an interesting quarter. Very solid results if a little more uneven than we would typically like. Enterprise & Infrastructure was disappointing in total, but that underperformance was isolated an
componenttext:
Thank you, Forbes. Well, the first fiscal quarter of 2012 is an interesting quarter. Very solid results if a little more uneven than we would typically like. Enterprise & Infrastructure was disappointing in total, but that underperformance was isolated and we feel confident about prospects for Enterprise & Infrastructure going forward. 
We have very good customer relationships in this segment with stable to expanding share of wallet in all major business relationships. We do expect margins to continue expansion as revenue growth -- as we experience revenue growth over the balance of the year, along with the benefits of cost reductions already underway in certain sites in Western Europe.
Very strong results and overperformance from our Diversified Manufacturing Services group, outstanding margin performance as well as sequential and year-over-year revenue growth. 
Many of you might be interested in a specific High Velocity customer, which I want to forewarn you we will not be able to answer any questions about specific customer relationships. However, recognizing the state of uncertain generally and as a result of some of the more uneven results in fiscal Q2, we thought it'd be helpful to help you understand and characterize the balance of our fiscal year. We've prepared some material to help you along with how we see the balance of the fiscal year for our company. If you could please turn to Slide 12. 
Using our fiscal first quarter results and the midpoint of our fiscal second quarter guidance, revenue for the first half of fiscal '12 should be approximately $8.4 billion. In the second half of the year, we expect the Diversified Manufacturing group to continue leading growth. We have the organic growth contribution from Aftermarket Services, which is typically at least 12% to 15% per year, combined with the benefit of the Telmar acquisition. We also continue to expect results in Materials Technology Group and the industrial & clean tech and the healthcare & instrumentation business areas to continue expansion over the course of the year. 
Given our market share and relatively stable demand trends in the Enterprise & Infrastructure group, and I want to highlight that, we see relatively stable demand trends in Enterprise & Infrastructure. And we see growth in the second half exceeding the first half, which we think is reasonable.
We're being conservative about revenue performance in High Velocity in the second of the year. This chart would indicate we're expecting a contraction of approximately $110 million in the second half of the year. However, the quality of that revenue in High Velocity and the margins should continue to be above the high end of our long-term targeted margin range. 
In essence, as a result for the fiscal '12, we have approximately $9 billion in the second half and a  total year revenue of about $17.4 billion. We're not trying to handicap anything more or less into this picture, just providing you a viewpoint as to where we think we are today and how the balance of the year might unfold.
Please turn to Slide 13. Should the year unfold at about this level, I would regard this as a solid year with a good trend in business mix toward the Diversified Manufacturing Services business area. Margin and profit expansion can take place on a much more moderate revenue growth, which I would regard as a very good thing. 
Please turn to Slide 14. Diversified Manufacturing Services group growth is underpinned by a very substantial market opportunity for the company, approximately a $500 billion addressable market with very low levels of penetration. And you can find this chart highlighted on our annual report, the fiscal '12 annual report, and that actually goes into additional detail of market subsegments in each of these business areas. Jabil has a leading or at least a beachhead position in all of these areas, and we look to significant growth in these areas over the next 3, 4, 5 years.
Turn to Slide 15, please. So in summary, we regard our first fiscal quarter and the fiscal year to be solid performance in an uncertain environment. We expect moderate revenue growth in fiscal '12. That's a little bit lower than what we just -- experience historically. But good solid revenue growth underpinned by a strong improvement in portfolio mix towards Diversified Manufacturing Services.
We are continuing our focus on lean manufacturing and operating efficiency, and all of these elements combined will help us keep us on track towards a third consecutive record year for the company in terms of revenue, income and EPS. Long-term business objectives remain on track, and we look forward to fiscal '12 and fiscal '13 and beyond.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Amitabh Passi.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: First question for you. I think last quarter you talked about the business having to sort of outgrow despite the weak macroeconomic environment. We've now seen year-over-year growth trends decelerate from like 32% to 4%. I'm just wondering how you would s
componenttext: First question for you. I think last quarter you talked about the business having to sort of outgrow despite the weak macroeconomic environment. We've now seen year-over-year growth trends decelerate from like 32% to 4%. I'm just wondering how you would sort of explain that. And is your expectation that sort of mid-single digits is now a more reasonable growth target for fiscal '12?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, 7% to 8% growth is significantly above macroeconomic growth and, in fact, I think would be a leading position in terms of S&P 500 companies. I mean, I think that's based on what we see today. So our long-term growth objectives remain on track, 20% t
componenttext: Well, 7% to 8% growth is significantly above macroeconomic growth and, in fact, I think would be a leading position in terms of S&P 500 companies. I mean, I think that's based on what we see today. So our long-term growth objectives remain on track, 20% to 30% in Diversified Manufacturing Services and 5% to 10% in the other business areas. If we look back in fiscal '12 over growth in fiscal '11 and '12, we'll certainly be, if not in the range, above the range of growth for those business areas. So I'm having a hard time getting to your interpretation of where we are. And actually, this growth is in terms of top line growth. It might be a little bit below were analysts had us in the -- after the conference call in September. But given the portfolio mix towards Diversified Manufacturing Services, the income and EPS associated with this revenue stream is roughly equivalent. So I would regard this as a nice trade-out of lower-margin revenue for a better earnings profile and more sustainability. So I think I'd take fiscal '12 particularly in this environment.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just as a quick follow-up perhaps for you, Forbes. Can you help us understand what we should expect in terms of operating margin expectations for HVS and E&I? I think HVS certainly surprised on the upside and E&I on the downside. Just for the Feb
componenttext: And then just as a quick follow-up perhaps for you, Forbes. Can you help us understand what we should expect in terms of operating margin expectations for HVS and E&I? I think HVS certainly surprised on the upside and E&I on the downside. Just for the February quarter, how we should be thinking about movements for these 2 segments?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'll certainly give you some color in general terms, and I'll provide specific guidance around each of these segments. But let's take Enterprise & Infrastructure first, which underperformed in the first quarter. That's really now about revenue gro
componenttext: Yes, so I'll certainly give you some color in general terms, and I'll provide specific guidance around each of these segments. But let's take Enterprise & Infrastructure first, which underperformed in the first quarter. That's really now about revenue growth. And as we have said in  the prepared remarks, essentially the guidance we're providing is it'll grow through the balance of the second fiscal quarter and the balance of the year. So we should see some pretty reasonable margin progression. I'll remind you that last quarter, we discussed the closure of our sites in Northern Italy. So there -- those -- that's underway. We'd anticipate that, that does occur. There'll be some benefit in the February quarter, obviously, and lead to margin accretion. And then we'd see the full benefit of those closures in the third or fourth quarter. But principally, we add back the revenue, we see the growth and we'll start to see margins progress from 2.5%. And I would expect us to be very close to the low end of our operating targets as we head -- as we get to the first fiscal quarter here. I remind everyone that the long-term target is in a range of 4% to 4.5%. In terms of the High Velocity arena, as you see, extremely pleased with the performance in the first fiscal quarter. And the way we think about that is that we did have some high utilization of assets in a seasonally high first quarter. So I would expect some decline in those margins as we move forward through the balance of the year. Sequentially, we do see revenues coming down as a result of this November high season. So the way to think about that is probably certainly above the high end of our targeted range, 2.5%, to somewhere around probably approaching the 3% for the balance of the year.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I fully understand. What drove the revenue degradation? It sounds like there was one inbound program when that just got changed towards the end. And is that -- the expectation that as that ramp happens, you should see revenues and margins start to improve
componenttext: I fully understand. What drove the revenue degradation? It sounds like there was one inbound program when that just got changed towards the end. And is that -- the expectation that as that ramp happens, you should see revenues and margins start to improve?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The revenue underperformance from Enterprise & Infrastructure in Q1 was driven by -- really characterized as about $106 million to $170 million revenue miss. About half was associated with excess inventory, buffer inventory to cover inbound transition of
componenttext: The revenue underperformance from Enterprise & Infrastructure in Q1 was driven by -- really characterized as about $106 million to $170 million revenue miss. About half was associated with excess inventory, buffer inventory to cover inbound transition of programs from a large customer. And they've set a buffer inventory that was larger than needed to support that product transition, and we're working down those buffers now with that customer. And then there was a couple of other customers that are just going through general inventory correction, which we think will rectify very quickly. So I think it's really important to say that the underlying demand is relatively stable. We just happened to get hit but with 2, 3 isolated circumstances of inbound transition issues and there's been a couple of inventory corrections.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. Yes, that's actually very helpful. And then, Forbes, just to understand the cash flow from operations, typically Q1, I think, tends to be the softer quarter and then  it tends to improve over the next quarter. So I'm actually surprised you had $10
componenttext: Got it. Yes, that's actually very helpful. And then, Forbes, just to understand the cash flow from operations, typically Q1, I think, tends to be the softer quarter and then  it tends to improve over the next quarter. So I'm actually surprised you had $100 million-plus of cash flow this quarter. Should we expect cash flow to continue to improve throughout fiscal '12 as it historically tends to do?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it should. And you're absolutely right. This -- we did an outstanding job in overall working management this quarter. So as we move forward through the balance of the year, I would expect continued strong cash flow from operations performance
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it should. And you're absolutely right. This -- we did an outstanding job in overall working management this quarter. So as we move forward through the balance of the year, I would expect continued strong cash flow from operations performance. So we certainly -- we annualize [ph]  to produce somewhere in the region of $175 million to $200 million-plus a quarter as we look out through the balance of the year. So that -- given what -- some of the CapEx and the acquisition of Telmar that -- both on the 1st of December, it'll certainly allow us, I think, to certainly return somewhere between -- $210 million of free cash flow in the fiscal year. So again, another very strong year from the working capital and cash flow perspective.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. Can I just ask a last one? If you could shape the $410 million of incremental revenues in the back half in 3 different greens [ph]? Is there any -- so could you say how much would come from specialized services versus health and Industrial?
componenttext: Fair enough. Can I just ask a last one? If you could shape the $410 million of incremental revenues in the back half in 3 different greens [ph]? Is there any -- so could you say how much would come from specialized services versus health and Industrial?

componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- roughly, if I kind of look at the board, I'd say roughly $75 million to $100 million would come from -- actually, about half would come from specialized services and half would come from the other business areas.
componenttext: Yes, it's -- roughly, if I kind of look at the board, I'd say roughly $75 million to $100 million would come from -- actually, about half would come from specialized services and half would come from the other business areas.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: If I look at your guidance for the E&I revenue in Q2, it doesn't look like you're expecting much of a sequential increase, maybe 1% or 2%. So I'm just trying to reconcile the revenue outlook for that segment with your comment that the Q1 shortfall was tem
componenttext: If I look at your guidance for the E&I revenue in Q2, it doesn't look like you're expecting much of a sequential increase, maybe 1% or 2%. So I'm just trying to reconcile the revenue outlook for that segment with your comment that the Q1 shortfall was temporary and unusual.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian, this is Forbes. The sequential guidance is about 3% as we move forward. So that's actually above what we typically see in this February quarter. As we move -- and Tim articulated in answer to previous question those end markets are relatively
componenttext: Yes, Brian, this is Forbes. The sequential guidance is about 3% as we move forward. So that's actually above what we typically see in this February quarter. As we move -- and Tim articulated in answer to previous question those end markets are relatively stable from our perspective, and the customer relationships. Other than that, the inbound inventory correction that we saw. But we are seeing growth. We have seen that occur in the last couple of weeks here in December. So yes, we're seeing growth, and we'd expect continued growth from the back half of the fiscal year also.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the margins, Forbes, the 60% decline in profitability year-over-year. Can you break that out? How much of that was due to the one-time restructuring actions versus the operating losses in your European facilities versus maybe some o
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the margins, Forbes, the 60% decline in profitability year-over-year. Can you break that out? How much of that was due to the one-time restructuring actions versus the operating losses in your European facilities versus maybe some of the lower-than-expected volumes that you talked about?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in terms of the lower-than-expected volumes, typically what we see in that instance is about a 10% deleverage on our revenue. Okay? So that's about $16 million to $18 million of an impact there because it was late in the quarter. In terms of the y
componenttext: Yes, so in terms of the lower-than-expected volumes, typically what we see in that instance is about a 10% deleverage on our revenue. Okay? So that's about $16 million to $18 million of an impact there because it was late in the quarter. In terms of the year-over-year basis, in our first fiscal quarter of last year, as you're aware, we didn't have sites in France and Italy, which are predominantly Enterprise & Infrastructure-focused sites. So this quarter, there was an impact there somewhere between 50 and 70 basis points on that margin. So add those back, we start to be at something north of 3 points and -- approaching 3, 3.5 points. I think, the math will show that. And as I said earlier, we have started this restructuring process. We do expect to be with the sites in our Northern Italy locations by the end of February. That's the current target. And we should then see continued pickup in Q3 and then Q4 again as we see revenues continue to ramp towards the low end of our targeted range of 4 to 4.5 points.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Lou Miscioscia.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Lou Miscioscia.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
