componenttext: Yes, maybe if you go to Diversified Manufacturing and E&I. I know you just mentioned E&I seemed stable. I guess you gained that trend into -- well into the first half, and also that same comment on Diversified Manufacturing. You commented that you're growing above the macro economy. But was that mostly due to the winds? Or is it macro economy from what you're seeing from your customers, maybe a little bit above 1%?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The comment about macroeconomic activity was in response to an assertion that Jabil's growth no longer would exceed the macro activity generally. And it certainly will, even with this year with revenue growth moderating. In terms of Enterprise & Infrastru
componenttext: The comment about macroeconomic activity was in response to an assertion that Jabil's growth no longer would exceed the macro activity generally. And it certainly will, even with this year with revenue growth moderating. In terms of Enterprise & Infrastructure, Lou, was -- what was your specific question there?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, just try -- basically about end demand broadly.
componenttext: Yes, just try -- basically about end demand broadly.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, end demand is actually pretty decent and stable. I mean actually, if you go back and look at previous years, Q1 is typically not a very good quarter for us. We had a decline in sequential growth in '10, and a decline in sequential growth in '11 and a
componenttext: Yes, end demand is actually pretty decent and stable. I mean actually, if you go back and look at previous years, Q1 is typically not a very good quarter for us. We had a decline in sequential growth in '10, and a decline in sequential growth in '11 and a little bit more of a sequential decline this quarter, but Q2 growth rebound. So underlying demand trends are okay. And that's why we're pointing to a few isolated customer relationships. We don't want to give investors the wrong message because this always seems to flow back to specific customers, which can be embarrassing and frankly is not true. Computing -- the storage market was actually a bright spot, and we've seen very stable to upper [ph] demand, and we're growing share of wallet in the storage business area. The telecommunications area, particularly wireless infrastructure demand is good, but we're seeing some inventory leveling and some technology changes that elongate some of the product transitions to Jabil. And then the other elements of Enterprise & Infrastructure, nothing to write home about in terms of great growth, but decent stability. And I think most of the marketplace has been sensitized to expect lower levels of annual year-over-year growth in the data communications area in particular. So I think it's nothing remarkable. We're certainly disappointed in the first fiscal quarter performance relative to our expectation. But relative to previous years' performance in fiscal Q1, not a great deal worse than in fiscal '11 and fiscal '10. And actually, when we look through the balance of the year, very high confidence levels that our revenue growth will resume growth in Q2 and continue throughout the year.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And High Velocity...
componenttext: And High Velocity...

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Diversified Manufacturing Services, you had a similar question in Diversified Manufacturing Services?
componenttext: Diversified Manufacturing Services, you had a similar question in Diversified Manufacturing Services?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Just what you're seeing I guess from a demand perspective.
componenttext: Yes, sure. Just what you're seeing I guess from a demand perspective.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think demand there is really robust given the transition from vertically integrated factories to the virtual manufacturing model when you talk about industrial and healthcare companies. Renewable energy is still good. There are some elements of ren
componenttext: Yes, I think demand there is really robust given the transition from vertically integrated factories to the virtual manufacturing model when you talk about industrial and healthcare companies. Renewable energy is still good. There are some elements of renewable energy that can be a bit choppy at this point but certainly a robust, long-term growth area. The Materials Technology Group has a very robust demand and -- although we do see some seasonality in that business in Q2 given the seasonal sell-through of the smartphone products that manufacturers' technology group builds for. And then the Aftermarket Services area, the Telmar acquisition, solid year-over-year organic growth on a steady basis. So DMS, Diversified Manufacturing Services, we expect to continue to see very robust demand for the services we provide.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Wamsi Mohan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Wamsi Mohan.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, you highlighted a $600 million incremental revenue in the second half versus first half, and it's about the same as what you did last fiscal year if you exclude the Telmar acquisition. So maybe you can share what you're seeing in the pipeline that's
componenttext: Tim, you highlighted a $600 million incremental revenue in the second half versus first half, and it's about the same as what you did last fiscal year if you exclude the Telmar acquisition. So maybe you can share what you're seeing in the pipeline that's giving you the confidence that you can do the same incremental dollar growth when arguably the uncertainty, it seems much higher in the near term.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure -- I don't know that the uncertainty is increasing. I think the talking heads on TV are pulling their hair out at a faster rate, but I think the overall economic environment isn't getting a lot worse or a lot better, not changing rapidly. Thi
componenttext: I'm not sure -- I don't know that the uncertainty is increasing. I think the talking heads on TV are pulling their hair out at a faster rate, but I think the overall economic environment isn't getting a lot worse or a lot better, not changing rapidly. Things seem to be a little bit better in the United States, a little bit slower in Europe. Asia continues to be stable. So I think that the economic environment is relatively benign, if you will, in terms of influence. $600 million of incremental revenue growth, as you point out, is pretty similar to what we had last year. We see -- if you look at the Enterprise & Infrastructure portion of that, we essentially get back $166 million that wasn't there in fiscal Q1 because that's a share of wallet issue and a sell-through rate issue. So once that inventory is consumed and the product transitions are completed, you get that -- basically that same run rate back into the revenue stream. And then there are some additional customer programs we expect to ramp in the production over the course of Q3 and Q4. So we feel good about it in Enterprise & Infrastructure, actually a very good line of sight to that as well. And then in Diversified Manufacturing Services, gosh, we're 30% year-over-year in Q1. Materials Technology, Aftermarket Services, industrial all have very good growth prospects through the balance of the year. We're actually even seeing growth in areas like defense and aerospace. So we feel good about the line of sight to growth in those areas as well. And I think one of the reasons we went through this, we want to make sure that investors are in touch with the -- what we think is a realistic perspective on the High Velocity business segment and actually seeing that contract in the second half of the year. And that attenuates the revenue growth for the year. Yet again, the margin profile and earnings power of the company is unaffected by that -- actually improved by that change out of High Velocity revenue for Enterprise & Infrastructure and Diversified Manufacturing Services. So it's actually a pretty good trade-out in our calculus of how the year should unfold. I think what you've got to do to put faith in this is you've got to believe that macroeconomic conditions continue at about the same rate. And again, I made the comment in -- during my prepared remarks that we're not trying to handicap anything more or less into this guidance, simply what we see today based on sell-through rates in the current economic environment. If you're someone who thinks the environment is going to get a lot worse, then this is probably something you won't have faith in. If you believe the economic environment will probably continue to be relatively tepid or lackluster, I think this is something you can put a lot of faith in. And I think the company has put up spectacular results in the face of significant macroeconomic headwinds, and I don't think those headwinds are any worse today than they have been in fiscal '11 or previously. So we wanted to help people understand how we see the balance of the year given all the moving parts and all of the collateral information that people have been getting over the last 3 or 4 months and worrying about, frankly. So we're looking for what we think is a pretty solid year, maybe a little bit lower revenue growth, but earnings that will compare very favorably with fiscal '11.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then a quick clarification on the High Velocity $110 million decline in the second half. Is that an expectation of just broad based more or fairly concentrated sort of across a couple of customers?
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then a quick clarification on the High Velocity $110 million decline in the second half. Is that an expectation of just broad based more or fairly concentrated sort of across a couple of customers?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's fairly concentrated in specific product categories. I think it's kind of interesting. If you look at High Velocity year-over-year in fiscal Q1, we've really reduced our exposure to the mobility EMS handset business and the TV set displays business. T
componenttext: It's fairly concentrated in specific product categories. I think it's kind of interesting. If you look at High Velocity year-over-year in fiscal Q1, we've really reduced our exposure to the mobility EMS handset business and the TV set displays business. The rest -- if you exclude the displays and the handset business, the rest of High Velocity is actually very stable to up year-over-year. And businesses like automotive have been robust. Our printing business is strong with good year-over-year growth. So point-of-sale systems is good. And so we're actually excluding the areas of the business where we've kind of intentionally pushed away from or de-emphasized. High Velocity is actually in pretty good shape. So that revenue degradation is specific to certain product areas.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Harrison.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Harrison.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on HVS. I mean with margins running better than kind of the long-term target here and you de-emphasizing some of the EMS handset-type business and the panels, I guess what would push it back toward that 2.5% target as you get into fiscal
componenttext: Just a follow-up on HVS. I mean with margins running better than kind of the long-term target here and you de-emphasizing some of the EMS handset-type business and the panels, I guess what would push it back toward that 2.5% target as you get into fiscal '13? Is it solely mix? Or is there something else that we should be looking for? Or, on the other hand, can it run at 3% going forward?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's reasonable to think that High Velocity, given what we see today, can run for the year at above -- at about 3% or a little bit better. So it would be above our long term of our targeted range. And I think opportunistically, it's an oppor
componenttext: Well, I think it's reasonable to think that High Velocity, given what we see today, can run for the year at above -- at about 3% or a little bit better. So it would be above our long term of our targeted range. And I think opportunistically, it's an opportunistic business area by nature. If we find opportunities to expand the business, we'd be looking for areas where there's higher value-add opportunities for the company. I think we'll take a look at our long-term targets for High Velocity closer to the end of the year when we kind of refresh for fiscal year '13. But I think it's -- I think Forbes and I would be comfortable with the expectation that High Velocity operating margins for the year can start with a 3, probably somewhere in the low 3s. And we expect to see -- I don't recall if we mentioned this in our prepared remarks or Q&A, but we do see the Enterprise & Infrastructure margins improving over the course of the year by about 50 basis points per quarter. So if you kind of do that and you've got consistent margins in the Diversified Manufacturing Services area, which we think is a reasonable expectation, that's why we think the earnings power of the company is in pretty good shape for the year.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, very helpful. And then just as a brief follow-up, I guess. Inventory expectations for the February quarter, would you expect inventory dollars to decline? And then on the buyback, I guess what are you looking at in terms of the stock price, anything
componenttext: Okay, very helpful. And then just as a brief follow-up, I guess. Inventory expectations for the February quarter, would you expect inventory dollars to decline? And then on the buyback, I guess what are you looking at in terms of the stock price, anything like that, just to maybe complete the $100 million authorization out there?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me have the last portion on price. As we noted in the prepared remarks, we do have an authorization of $100 million available to us. And the intent there is that they use that during the fiscal year. So you should start to see us put that into ac
componenttext: Yes, let me have the last portion on price. As we noted in the prepared remarks, we do have an authorization of $100 million available to us. And the intent there is that they use that during the fiscal year. So you should start to see us put that into action as we move through the coming quarters here, but wouldn't expect us to use that in any one particular quarter but a measured approach as we move through the balance of the fiscal year. In terms of inventory, yes, we should absolutely see trends of declines in inventory. And we certainly expect to gain back the -- was it $160 million or so sequential increase in the quarter to bring that back down to Q4 levels overall.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Sheerin.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Sheerin.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a question on DMS. Tim, you talked about -- you gave some guidance for growth for the next quarter. And then you also talked about some seasonality in the material side, particularly with Green Point and the smartphone exposure there. But aside from
componenttext: Just a question on DMS. Tim, you talked about -- you gave some guidance for growth for the next quarter. And then you also talked about some seasonality in the material side, particularly with Green Point and the smartphone exposure there. But aside from Green Point and the smartphone exposure, is there much seasonality to that business? Because over the last few quarters, you've been growing sequentially ever quarter and -- obviously with the good pipeline. But how do you see that playing out from a seasonality standpoint aside from some of the specialized manufacturing business?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, experience would say that it's typically not a great quarter for growth anyways. I mean even though we're not relying on end market growth and Diversified Manufacturing Services is really planning on market penetration of our industry, it still tend
componenttext: Well, experience would say that it's typically not a great quarter for growth anyways. I mean even though we're not relying on end market growth and Diversified Manufacturing Services is really planning on market penetration of our industry, it still tends to be a relatively slow period. That said, so no, there's not much seasonality, although it tends to be -- it's not intuitive that it's seasonal, but it tends to be a relatively slow period anyways and just based on our empirical evidence of behaviors. But looking at the pipeline of growth in those businesses, industrial, the clean tech area, the healthcare area, very, very strong performance. We do have some exposure in the instrumentation part of healthcare instrumentation. There is some semiconductor capital equipment content that is very weak right now and when that runs through the system, I think we'll see good year-over-year growth as the balance of the year unfolds.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then looking at Thailand, I know you have a little bit of exposure in manufacturing on the industrial side there. And then obviously it's a big source of supply and components, particularly on the hard drive side. Have you seen any impact
componenttext: Okay, great. And then looking at Thailand, I know you have a little bit of exposure in manufacturing on the industrial side there. And then obviously it's a big source of supply and components, particularly on the hard drive side. Have you seen any impact at all, negative or positive, from Thailand both from a customer standpoint and a supply standpoint?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Very, very little. There's some impact, but very little impact to Q1. I think we'll probably see some impact in Q2. We've got some actual -- a number of things going on in Q2 that are handicapped into the guidance. So I don't want to belabor the point. Bu
componenttext: Very, very little. There's some impact, but very little impact to Q1. I think we'll probably see some impact in Q2. We've got some actual -- a number of things going on in Q2 that are handicapped into the guidance. So I don't want to belabor the point. But there's Chinese New Year, there's fewer working days in Q2. There will be some impact in our High Velocity business area related to set-top boxes, we anticipate, due to the Thailand flooding. And our guys are working feverishly to offset those -- that impact, but expectation's now there will be -- there'll be some impact, but relatively modest.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just quickly, could you tell us who the top -- who the 3 10% customers were in the quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And just quickly, could you tell us who the top -- who the 3 10% customers were in the quarter?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't name names at this time of the year. But we talked about them being in 3 different segments, one in High Velocity, one in Enterprise & Infrastructure that most people are familiar with and the other being in the Diversified Manufacturing Se
componenttext: Well, we don't name names at this time of the year. But we talked about them being in 3 different segments, one in High Velocity, one in Enterprise & Infrastructure that most people are familiar with and the other being in the Diversified Manufacturing Services area, which is new for us.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve O'Brien.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve O'Brien.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones here at the end maybe on your last point, Tim. Would you be able to tell us where the new DMS 10% customer falls within the 3 categories of DMS?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones here at the end maybe on your last point, Tim. Would you be able to tell us where the new DMS 10% customer falls within the 3 categories of DMS?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well again, I'd like to be very specific, but this stuff always flows back. I'm in customer relationships and that's why we don't name names, particularly at this time of the year. But if you take a look at the pie chart, you can see very significant grow
componenttext: Well again, I'd like to be very specific, but this stuff always flows back. I'm in customer relationships and that's why we don't name names, particularly at this time of the year. But if you take a look at the pie chart, you can see very significant growth in the specialized services area. So make your own bets there.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Looking out at the CapEx this quarter I think that the expectation, if I wrote it down right, was that CapEx might be a little bit lower in fiscal '12 versus '11, but kind of we're at parity sort of one quarter end. And clearly, it sounds like there
componenttext: Okay. Looking out at the CapEx this quarter I think that the expectation, if I wrote it down right, was that CapEx might be a little bit lower in fiscal '12 versus '11, but kind of we're at parity sort of one quarter end. And clearly, it sounds like there's some ramping expected for the second half of the year. So, I guess we just want to check in to see if we should be revising that CapEx expectation. And secondly on free cash flow, with respect to sort of the range of outcomes, would you expect it to be sort of lower as the year strengthens on working capital and higher if it kind of remains the same or not?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, in terms of the CapEx, we guided into the first quarter right about $100 million. We came in slightly on point, $95 million actually for the first quarter. So our overall expectations for the year, if we add in our second fiscal quarter, the p
componenttext: Yes, Steve, in terms of the CapEx, we guided into the first quarter right about $100 million. We came in slightly on point, $95 million actually for the first quarter. So our overall expectations for the year, if we add in our second fiscal quarter, the point of guidance is $85 million. It's actually somewhere between $350 million to $400 million in terms of capital expenditures for the year is where our thoughts are currently. So last year, we spent on a net basis, I think, $426 million, something of that nature. So a little bit shy of that. In addition, obviously we -- you have this "Telmar acquisition" of about $130 million. So investors at that point in terms of modeling cash flow. In terms of the overall cash flows, I think the question related to performance in terms of the cash flow depending on revenue growth. Currently, with the back half of the year that we articulated in the prepared remarks today, our working capital management has really been, in my opinion, outstanding over the last multiple quarters, the last 5 or 6 quarters. And I don't see anything that would change that level of performance as I look through the balance of the fiscal year. So what that does, based on the view we have of the balance of our fiscal year, certainly provides us an opportunity of somewhere in that $175 million, $200 million-plus a quarter of operating cash flow. Take off these CapEx levels and expenditures [ph] that we talked about and you're producing $250 million of free cash flow for the year. If revenue should grow faster than our current view of the back half of the fiscal year, there will be some degradation to those cash flows purely based upon the amount of working capital that we need. And the way we typically think about that is somewhere in the region of $0.05 to $0.10 of our working capital need for every incremental dollar of revenue. Should we see softness, then clearly cash flows will outperform these levels I've just discussed.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, just following up on the HVS and expected decline in the back half of the year, anything else you could point to in terms of diversity of the rest of your customer base or just the visibility into new pipelines or wins that would help potentially eas
componenttext: Tim, just following up on the HVS and expected decline in the back half of the year, anything else you could point to in terms of diversity of the rest of your customer base or just the visibility into new pipelines or wins that would help potentially ease some of the concern or risk around the decline in HVS?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the decline in HVS is limited to certain business areas. And I think most people following the company can probably put that together. But our automotive business is in High Velocity. That's actually grown significantly year-over-year. Our point-of-s
componenttext: Yes, the decline in HVS is limited to certain business areas. And I think most people following the company can probably put that together. But our automotive business is in High Velocity. That's actually grown significantly year-over-year. Our point-of-sale business is in decent shape. Our printing business is very strong, up this year. The displays and mobility, the handset parts of the business are in decline. And the displays, I think, investors are very aware of year-over-year. So those compares will actually start to get a little bit easier when display's part of it. I mean, our set-top box business has been stable. So those are the business areas. There are new wins. It's very stable market share. As I said if you exclude the handset and the displays part of the business, High Velocity is growing. It's a slow growth, but it's growing.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could just follow up with that and then on the new 10% customer in DMS. Any type of visibility from that customer in terms of -- would it be our expectation that, that is consistently a 10% customer through the year? Or how's your visibility th
componenttext: Okay. If I could just follow up with that and then on the new 10% customer in DMS. Any type of visibility from that customer in terms of -- would it be our expectation that, that is consistently a 10% customer through the year? Or how's your visibility there?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think they'll continue to be a 10% customer, yes.
componenttext: I think they'll continue to be a 10% customer, yes.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last one, if I could, for Forbes. You mentioned the 14% increase in the dividend. Given the increased cash flows that you are generating, any thoughts on why the dividend -- you couldn't do more in terms of bumping it up?
componenttext: Okay. And last one, if I could, for Forbes. You mentioned the 14% increase in the dividend. Given the increased cash flows that you are generating, any thoughts on why the dividend -- you couldn't do more in terms of bumping it up?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we just took that up 30, 40 days ago, I think. But certainly, as we look through the fiscal year, we always keep that in front of mind as we look at our overall capital return policy to shareholders. So let's continue to put up the cash flows.
componenttext: Yes. Well, we just took that up 30, 40 days ago, I think. But certainly, as we look through the fiscal year, we always keep that in front of mind as we look at our overall capital return policy to shareholders. So let's continue to put up the cash flows. I mean a great start to the year. We'll continue to perform at these types of levels in the coming quarters. And we'll certainly keep that front of mind as we review our dividend policy in the next fiscal year.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Craig, I think it's a really fair question. We've had a number of investors ask us to articulate our policy around dividends and share repurchases in some relationship to free cash flow, operating profit, some metric that investors can use to hold managem
componenttext: Craig, I think it's a really fair question. We've had a number of investors ask us to articulate our policy around dividends and share repurchases in some relationship to free cash flow, operating profit, some metric that investors can use to hold management accountable for return of value to shareholders. We're not prepared to articulate that today, but we are working on that type of policy. And we think by the time we start talking about fiscal '13, Forbes and I will have a position on how we look at dividends long term and share repurchases and the role they play and how we deploy free cash flow. I think having said that, we're not a company that thinks that the management team should [indiscernible] all excess cash. We think our first priority is to invest the cash in the business. We had a slide that showed our 26% GAAP income return on invested capital. Our cost of capital is under 9%. So this is a very high return on investment of the dollars, and we'll look to have that be consistent in terms of investing in the business. But beyond that, we will look to dividend expansion and share repurchases and other ways of returning capital.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Suva.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Suva.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: When we look at the EPS and leverage potential for Jabil, it's been a long time since we've kind of had a steady environment. A lot of up cycles, down cycles in the past few years. It looks like for calendar Q1, sales were up about year-over-year about 6%
componenttext: When we look at the EPS and leverage potential for Jabil, it's been a long time since we've kind of had a steady environment. A lot of up cycles, down cycles in the past few years. It looks like for calendar Q1, sales were up about year-over-year about 6%, and EPS was up about 6% year-over-year and if I do my math right for the full fiscal year, it looks like sales will be up about 5% to 5.3% or so year-over-year for the full fiscal '12. For the EPS leverage, since Q1 was in line with the sales growth, I also recognize you're going through a lot of restructuring that should bear fruit in the second half of the year. Should we look for EPS to grow faster than sales? And what type of rate? Kind of like twice the sales or 1.5x of sales? Or how should we think about the leverage in the model to the bottom line?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jim, just keep in mind when you compare our fiscal Q1 '12 to fiscal Q1 '11, fiscal Q1 '11 does not include the operations in France and Italy that were acquired -- re-acquired. And that diluted income, $5 million to $10 million, so there was some leverage
componenttext: Jim, just keep in mind when you compare our fiscal Q1 '12 to fiscal Q1 '11, fiscal Q1 '11 does not include the operations in France and Italy that were acquired -- re-acquired. And that diluted income, $5 million to $10 million, so there was some leverage. There's been some SG&A expansion. That's partly due to the re-acquisition of those sites. But there is some positive leverage. I think you will see, Jim, as you look out in Q3 and Q4, a more pronounced level of return of incremental revenue dollars associated with operating expense leverage as well as the shift to Diversified Manufacturing Services. Did you want to add anything to that, Forbes?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think that is correct. As we look into back half of the year based on our point of view of revenue there, we should see our core EPS growth expand at a faster rate than the '11 growth rate on a quarterly basis.
componenttext: No, I think that is correct. As we look into back half of the year based on our point of view of revenue there, we should see our core EPS growth expand at a faster rate than the '11 growth rate on a quarterly basis.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fox.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fox.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, just one question relative to the talking heads that you referenced. If they turn out to be maybe less transient in 2012 and the economy sort of grows slow, so you envision any of that pipeline that you've referenced maybe opening up sooner? Is there
componenttext: Tim, just one question relative to the talking heads that you referenced. If they turn out to be maybe less transient in 2012 and the economy sort of grows slow, so you envision any of that pipeline that you've referenced maybe opening up sooner? Is there a chance that customers are ready to assume that a slow growth environment can lead to more outsourcing? I mean, what's the upside from here relative to what could still be a stable economy next year?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a good question. I'm not sure how to convert the comment into -- I'm not sure how to quantitatively convert the comment. But a little bit of tailwind would be exponentially good for the business, particularly when you look at infrastruc
componenttext: Well, I think it's a good question. I'm not sure how to convert the comment into -- I'm not sure how to quantitatively convert the comment. But a little bit of tailwind would be exponentially good for the business, particularly when you look at infrastructure spend where we do have a pretty decent market share with customers in the -- except customers in the Enterprise & Infrastructure group. I guess some tailwind that would be exponentially better for the business. And I think just having a stable to slightly positively biased environment would put healthcare and industrial types of customers that are presently vertically integrated companies then would be a little bit more aggressive and comfortable with an outsourcing model. The level of uncertainty in not knowing which way things are going to go just naturally causes conservative people to pull their horns in. And an outstanding environment doesn't necessarily accelerate the outsourcing, but if there was a positive bias where they felt like the ground was firm underneath their feet, we might see an acceleration of outsourcing from presently vertically integrated companies.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And your last question for today's session will come from the line of Sherri Scribner.
componenttext: And your last question for today's session will come from the line of Sherri Scribner.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, I wanted to ask you about Diversified Manufacturing Services. That segment seems to be, at least this quarter, driven primarily by the specialized services segment. And if we look on a quarter-over-quarter basis, industrial and healthcare segments se
componenttext: Tim, I wanted to ask you about Diversified Manufacturing Services. That segment seems to be, at least this quarter, driven primarily by the specialized services segment. And if we look on a quarter-over-quarter basis, industrial and healthcare segments seem to be a bit weaker. Can you give us some outlook in terms of what you're seeing in those segments? And what are your expectations for the balance of the year? Do you expect specialized services to be the primary driver of growth in that segment?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think specialized services, given the acquisition of Telmar and the outstanding growth in Materials Technology Group, is that they will continue to lead the pack in terms of the Diversified Manufacturing Services. But we do see more significant growth f
componenttext: I think specialized services, given the acquisition of Telmar and the outstanding growth in Materials Technology Group, is that they will continue to lead the pack in terms of the Diversified Manufacturing Services. But we do see more significant growth from the healthcare & instrumentation and the industrial & clean tech groups in the second half of the year. And now unfortunately, we've not been able to turn growth in those areas into the linear growth ramps. They tend to be relatively stair step and come in some chunks with stair step and then moderate growth sequentially. And that's why we're really converting or thinking to looking at things in a year-over-year basis because it does a better job of characterizing the actual growth rate in those areas. The other thing I'd say, Sherri, is just looking at the present core and the present environment, the semi-cap equipment area of industrial & clean tech and the healthcare & instrumentation group, that is weak and diluting the results in that area. We expect that to kind of either stay where it is or maybe even modestly improve in fiscal '12, but not looking for -- that has the impact of diluting the sequential growth near term.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then just thinking about Chinese New Year, you did make a quick comment about it already, but is your expectation that Chinese New Year being earlier this year will be somewhat negative to the revenue growth for the quarter?
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then just thinking about Chinese New Year, you did make a quick comment about it already, but is your expectation that Chinese New Year being earlier this year will be somewhat negative to the revenue growth for the quarter?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Some folks in Asia seem to think so. I'm not sure why that would be the case. But we do have fewer working days. The company is producing a lot of its revenue in Asia and China specifically. And our Materials Technology Group has a lot of operations in Ch
componenttext: Some folks in Asia seem to think so. I'm not sure why that would be the case. But we do have fewer working days. The company is producing a lot of its revenue in Asia and China specifically. And our Materials Technology Group has a lot of operations in China as well. And so as our exposure has kind of inched up in the Asia market the last few years, it actually is becoming a little bit more meaningful on the margin.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you for joining us on the call today. We certainly will be available for follow-up throughout the balance of the week, the workweek, right? And happy holidays to everyone. Thank you.
componenttext: All right. Thank you for joining us on the call today. We certainly will be available for follow-up throughout the balance of the week, the workweek, right? And happy holidays to everyone. Thank you.
